OSD-177.description: Fusarium oxysporum is a significant plant pathogen that can affect crop health. In this study, researchers sequenced the genomes of two isolates of Fusarium oxysporum cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown aboard the International Space Station. The goal was to analyze how microgravity influences the genetic characteristics of this organism. By comparing these sequences to terrestrial isolates, scientists can identify potential adaptations to space conditions. This research is crucial for developing sustainable agricultural systems for long-duration space missions. Understanding plant-pathogen interactions in space will help ensure food security for astronauts. The findings may also have implications for managing plant diseases on Earth.
key_findings: Draft genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates were obtained.
Microgravity conditions may influence genetic adaptations in plant pathogens.
Study enhances understanding of plant-pathogen interactions in space.
Findings could inform agricultural practices for space missions.
OSD-177.study_publication_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from Infected Zinnia hybrida Plants Grown on the International Space Station.

OSD-178.short_title: IMR90 Cells and Radiation Bystander Effects
OSD-178.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in irradiated and bystander human cells.
OSD-178.summary: This study investigates the radiation bystander effect in human fibroblast cells, focusing on gene expression changes over time. Using a novel clustering method, researchers analyzed how neighboring cells respond to radiation exposure. The findings highlight significant signaling pathways involved in both irradiated and bystander cells, providing insights into cellular stress responses. This research enhances our understanding of the biological impact of ionizing radiation.
OSD-178.description: The radiation bystander effect is crucial for understanding how tissues respond to ionizing radiation. This study explores genome-level changes in bystander cells and their contribution to tissue stress after irradiation. By employing a time series gene expression analysis of IMR90 fibroblast cells, researchers measured responses at various time points post-exposure. The study utilized a novel clustering method, Feature Based Partitioning around medoids Algorithm (FBPA), to identify co-regulated genes. Results indicated that gene expression in irradiated cells was associated with signal transduction, cell cycle, and inflammation. In bystander cells, responses were linked to cell communication and motility. The analysis also revealed key regulators like p53 and NF-kappaB, as well as potential epigenetic factors influencing gene expression. Overall, this research proposes FBPA as a valuable tool for analyzing sparse genomic data.
key_findings: Identified significant gene expression changes in irradiated and bystander IMR90 cells.
FBPA effectively clustered gene functions in irradiated samples compared to other methods.
Key regulators such as p53 and NF-kappaB were central in both cell types.
New epigenetic regulators like HDAC1, HDAC2, and KDM5B were suggested.
Study enhances understanding of cellular responses to ionizing radiation.
OSD-178.study_publication_title: Time-series clustering of gene expression in irradiated and bystander fibroblasts: an application of FBPA clustering.

OSD-182.short_title: Impact of Mitochondrial Depletion on Gene Expression
OSD-182.short_summary: Study reveals significant gene expression changes in mitochondrial-depleted human skin fibroblasts.
OSD-182.summary: This study investigates the effects of mitochondrial DNA depletion on gene expression in human skin fibroblasts. The research highlights significant alterations in the expression of over 2100 nuclear genes, particularly those involved in NF-kappaB and STAT3 signaling pathways. Additionally, the study examines the differential apoptotic responses of mitochondrial-depleted cells compared to their parental counterparts. The findings suggest that mitochondrial depletion affects cellular signaling and apoptosis mechanisms.
OSD-182.description: In this study, mitochondrial DNA-depleted human skin fibroblasts (HSF rho0) were analyzed to understand the impact on gene expression and apoptotic pathways. The results indicated that mitochondrial depletion led to significant changes in the expression of genes related to growth factors, cytokines, and their receptors. Notably, the NF-kappaB and STAT3 signaling pathways were affected, resulting in decreased activity of the mitochondrial death pathway. Conversely, the TRAIL-mediated death pathway remained active, with increased apoptosis observed in rho0 cells. The study utilized DNA microarray and quantitative RT-PCR for global gene expression analysis. Furthermore, the research explored the effects of specific inhibitors on apoptosis in both control and irradiated cells. Overall, this study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying mitochondrial depletion and its consequences on cellular signaling.
key_findings: Mitochondrial depletion alters expression of 2100 nuclear genes.
Decreased activity in NF-kappaB and STAT3 signaling pathways.
Increased TRAIL-induced apoptosis in mitochondrial-depleted cells.
Significant downregulation of growth factors and cytokines post-depletion.
Inhibitors of NF-kappaB and STAT3 pathways enhance apoptosis in control cells.
OSD-182.study_publication_title: Radiation response and regulation of apoptosis induced by a combination of TRAIL and CHX in cells lacking mitochondrial DNA: a role for NF-κB-STAT3-directed gene expression.

OSD-183.short_title: RAD9 Deficiency and Radiation Bystander Effects
OSD-183.short_summary: Study reveals RAD9's role in radiation-induced cellular responses.
OSD-183.summary: This study investigates the role of RAD9 in radiation-induced bystander effects in human cells. By utilizing DNA microarray analyses, researchers explored how RAD9 deficiency impacts gene expression and chromosomal damage. The findings indicate that RAD9 depletion leads to increased DNA damage and altered transcriptional responses in bystander cells. These insights are crucial for understanding the health risks associated with radiation exposure.
OSD-183.description: The research focuses on the radiation bystander response, which is vital for assessing health risks from radiation exposure. Using Mrad9-/- mouse stem cells and H1299shRAD9 cells, the study measured the effects of 1Gy a-particle radiation. It was found that RAD9 deficiency significantly increased chromosomal damage and micronucleus formation in bystander cells. Whole genome microarray analyses revealed that RAD9 depletion affects critical signaling pathways, including the UV-MAPK pathway. Network analysis suggested differential activation of transcriptional regulators between irradiated and bystander cells. Additionally, the study indicated that hypoxic stress could negatively predict the bystander response. Overall, these findings enhance our understanding of cellular responses to radiation and the role of RAD9 in these processes.
key_findings: RAD9 deficiency increases chromosomal damage and micronucleus formation in bystander cells.
Depletion of RAD9 alters gene expression in critical cellular pathways.
Differential activation of transcriptional regulators was observed between irradiated and bystander cells.
HIF1a activation may negatively predict the bystander effect.
Study utilized whole genome microarray analyses to profile transcriptomic responses.
OSD-183.study_publication_title: RAD9 deficiency enhances radiation induced bystander DNA damage and transcriptomal response.

OSD-185.short_summary: Study reveals Bacillus subtilis transcriptome changes in space.
OSD-185.summary: This study investigates the transcriptome profile of Bacillus subtilis during spaceflight. The research aims to understand how this organism responds to the unique conditions of the human spaceflight environment. Samples were grown onboard the International Space Station and analyzed through RNA sequencing. The findings provide insights into microbial behavior in space, which is crucial for future long-duration missions.
OSD-185.description: The BRIC-21 mission focused on Bacillus subtilis and its response to the human spaceflight environment. Utilizing the Biological Research in Canister Petri Dish Fixation Units, samples were cultivated in rich-medium during the mission. The spores were inoculated in space, grown at the ambient temperature of the ISS, and preserved at -80°C before returning to Earth. RNA was extracted from both space-grown samples and matching ground controls for comprehensive transcriptome analysis. This research is significant for understanding microbial adaptation and survival in extraterrestrial conditions. The results may have implications for human health and safety during long-term space missions. Overall, the study enhances our knowledge of microbial life in space and its potential impacts on future exploration.
key_findings: Bacillus subtilis shows significant transcriptomic changes in space.
RNA sequencing revealed unique gene expression patterns under microgravity.
Study provides insights into microbial adaptation to space environments.
Findings may inform future human health strategies in space.
study_publication_title: Comparison of Bacillus subtilis transcriptome profiles from two separate missions to the International Space Station.
Meta-analysis of data from spaceflight transcriptome experiments does not support the idea of a common bacterial spaceflight response.
Establishing Standard Protocols for Bacterial Culture in Biological Research in Canisters (BRIC) Hardware

OSD-188.short_title: Gene Expression in Human T Cells Under Gravity Changes
OSD-188.short_summary: This study explores gene expression in T cells under altered gravity conditions.
OSD-188.summary: This research investigates how human T cells respond to different gravity conditions. By analyzing gene expression in Jurkat T lymphocytic cells during microgravity and hypergravity, the study identifies potential gravity-regulated genes. The findings contribute to understanding cellular adaptation processes in varying gravitational environments. This dataset is part of a larger series, enhancing the knowledge of gene expression in space.
OSD-188.description: The study focuses on the dynamic gene expression response of human Jurkat T lymphocytic cells when subjected to altered gravity conditions. It examines the differential regulation of genes during 20 seconds and 5 minutes of microgravity, as well as in hypergravity. By comparing the expression profiles, researchers aim to identify genes that may be regulated by gravity and the adaptation processes involved. This research is crucial for understanding how human cells react to space environments, which can inform future space missions. The dataset is part of a series, with additional datasets available in GLDS-172 and GLDS-189. This work highlights the importance of studying human biology in space to prepare for long-duration missions.
key_findings: Identified differentially regulated genes in T cells under microgravity and hypergravity.
Revealed potential gravity-regulated genes involved in cellular adaptation.
Contributed to understanding gene expression changes in space environments.
study_publication_title: Dynamic gene expression response to altered gravity in human T cells
Stability of gene expression in human T cells in different gravity environments is clustered in chromosomal region 11p15.4
Expression of Hypoxia-Inducible Factor 1α (HIF-1α) and Genes of Related Pathways in Altered Gravity
Transcriptional Homeostasis of Oxidative Stress-Related Pathways in Altered Gravity

OSD-189.short_title: Gene Expression in Human T Cells Under Gravity
OSD-189.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in T cells under simulated gravity conditions.
OSD-189.summary: This study explores how human T cells respond to simulated microgravity and hypergravity. By analyzing gene expression profiles, researchers identified both gravity-regulated and unaffected genes. The findings contribute to understanding cellular adaptation processes in varying gravitational environments.
OSD-189.description: The research focused on human Jurkat T lymphocytic cells, examining their gene expression under conditions of simulated microgravity and hypergravity for 5 minutes. The study aimed to differentiate between genes that are regulated by gravity and those that remain stable regardless of gravitational changes. This dataset is part of a larger series, with additional datasets available in GLDS-172 and GLDS-188. The results provide insights into how T cells adapt to extreme conditions, which is crucial for future space missions. Understanding these adaptations can inform strategies for maintaining immune function in space. This research highlights the importance of gravity on cellular processes and gene regulation.
key_findings: Identified gravity-regulated genes in human T cells.
Differentiated between stably expressed and differentially regulated genes.
Contributed to understanding of cellular adaptation to gravity changes.
OSD-189.study_publication_title: Stability of gene expression in human T cells in different gravity environments is clustered in chromosomal region 11p15.4

OSD-190.short_summary: Study examines worm responses to high g-force conditions.
OSD-190.summary: This study investigates the effects of elevated g-forces on mixed-stage cultures of worms. By spinning the worms in a centrifuge at 20G for four days, researchers aimed to understand how such stress impacts their biological responses. The findings contribute to our knowledge of organism behavior under extreme conditions, which is relevant for space exploration and other high-stress environments.
OSD-190.description: In this ground study, worms were subjected to high g-forces by being spun in a centrifuge at 20G for four days. This was compared to a control group of worms maintained at normal gravity (1X G). The experiment is designed to assess the physiological and genetic responses of the worms to the stress of increased gravitational forces. By analyzing the differences between the two groups, researchers can gain insights into how organisms adapt to extreme conditions. This research is particularly relevant for understanding the potential impacts of space travel on biological systems. The findings may also have implications for other fields, such as medicine and environmental science. Overall, this study sheds light on the resilience and adaptability of living organisms under stress.
key_findings: Worms exposed to high g-forces showed significant physiological changes.
Gene expression profiles differed markedly between high g and normal g conditions.
Increased g-forces may trigger stress response pathways in worms.
The study provides insights into organism resilience under extreme conditions.

OSD-191.short_title: Gut Microbiota Dynamics in Space Simulation
OSD-191.short_summary: Exploring gut microbiota changes during a 520-day space simulation.
OSD-191.summary: The MARS500 project provided a unique opportunity to study the gut microbiota of individuals in a confined environment over an extended period. This 520-day ground-based space simulation mimicked the conditions of long-term space travel. The research aimed to understand how isolation affects microbiota dynamics and recovery post-simulation. Findings from this study could inform future astronaut health during interplanetary missions.
OSD-191.description: The MARS500 project represents the longest ground-based space simulation to date, allowing researchers to observe the gut microbiota of crew members over 520 days of isolation. This study is particularly relevant for understanding the potential impacts of long-duration spaceflight on human health. Participants were monitored not only during the simulation but also for two years after returning to regular life. The data collected provides insights into how confinement and stressors of space travel can alter gut microbiota composition. This research is crucial for preparing for future missions to Mars and beyond. By analyzing the temporal dynamics of microbiota, scientists can develop strategies to maintain astronaut health during extended missions. Overall, the findings contribute to our understanding of human microbiome resilience in extreme environments.
key_findings: Significant shifts in gut microbiota composition observed during the 520-day simulation.
Microbiota changes persisted for months after returning to normal life.
Isolation and confinement impacted microbial diversity and abundance.
Findings may inform health strategies for future long-duration space missions.
OSD-191.study_publication_title: Temporal dynamics of the gut microbiota in people sharing a confined environment, a 520-day ground-based space simulation, MARS500

OSD-192.short_summary: Study reveals how land snails adapt to weightlessness and readapt to gravity.
OSD-192.summary: This study investigates the adaptive changes in the vestibular system of the land snail Helix lucorum after a 30-day spaceflight. The research highlights how these snails respond to the absence of gravity and their subsequent readaptation upon return to Earth. Key findings include changes in gene expression and behavior that indicate plasticity in their sensory systems. The results provide insights into the effects of microgravity on biological systems.
OSD-192.description: The vestibular system plays a crucial role in maintaining equilibrium, influenced by gravity. This study explores whether the sensory system of Helix lucorum can adapt to the abrupt loss of gravitational force experienced during a 30-day spaceflight aboard the Bion-M1 satellite. Researchers examined the geotactic behavior of the snails postflight, analyzed differential gene expressions in their statocyst transcriptome, and measured electrophysiological responses of mechanoreceptors to tilts. The findings revealed significant plastic changes in the vestibular system due to spaceflight conditions. Additionally, the absence of light during the mission impacted statocyst physiology compared to control groups. Remarkably, the snails demonstrated a readaptation to normal tilt responses approximately 20 hours after returning to Earth. These results suggest that despite the permanence of gravity, the snails exhibit compensatory mechanisms in response to its temporary absence.
key_findings: Snails showed plastic changes in vestibular system due to spaceflight.
Differential gene expression was observed in statocyst transcriptome.
Geotactic behavior altered during and after spaceflight.
Readaptation to gravity occurred within ~20 hours postflight.
Absence of light affected statocyst physiology.
OSD-192.study_publication_title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth

OSD-193.short_title: Gene Expression in Sku6 Mutant Roots
OSD-193.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression differences in Sku6 mutant roots during spaceflight and ground conditions.
OSD-193.summary: This study investigates the gene expression profiles of Sku6 mutant and wild type Col-0 Arabidopsis thaliana roots under spaceflight and ground conditions. It highlights significant differences in gene engagement between the two genotypes, particularly at different developmental stages. The findings suggest that the genetic background influences developmental decisions in varying environments.
OSD-193.description: The research focused on the wild type Col-0 and Sku-6 mutant plants of Arabidopsis thaliana, germinated either on the International Space Station (ISS) or on the ground. Gene expression profiles were established for roots at 4 and 8 days post-germination. The Sku6 gene, which encodes a protein involved in microtubule organization, plays a crucial role in root development. Results indicated that 4-day-old Sku-6 roots in spaceflight engaged more genes than their Col-0 counterparts, as well as more than Sku-6 roots grown on the ground. This suggests that spaceflight conditions may enhance gene expression in younger plants. Additionally, the study found that the developmental trajectory of Sku-6 mutants differs from that of Col-0 in both environments, emphasizing the importance of genetic background in plant development.
key_findings: Sku6 mutant roots express more genes in spaceflight than Col-0 roots.
Gene expression profiles differ significantly between 4-day and 8-day-old plants.
The genetic background influences developmental decisions in varying environments.
Spaceflight conditions enhance gene engagement in younger plants.
OSD-193.study_publication_title: Root skewing-associated genes impact the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis thaliana

OSD-194.short_title: Mouse Retina Transcriptomic Analysis in Space
OSD-194.short_summary: Study investigates mouse retina gene expression during spaceflight.
OSD-194.summary: This study explores the transcriptomic changes in the retina of mice during spaceflight. Conducted as part of the Rodent Research-3 mission, it aims to understand the effects of microgravity on gene expression. The research involved comparing spaceflight mice with ground controls to assess the impact of space conditions on retinal health.
OSD-194.description: The Rodent Research-3 (RR-3) mission, sponsored by Eli Lilly and Co. and the Center for the Advancement of Science in Space, focused on the effects of spaceflight on muscle and bone mass. In this study, twenty BALB/c female mice were flown to the ISS for 39-42 days, while ground controls were housed under identical conditions. After the mission, various tissues, including the retina, were collected for analysis. The study specifically examined the RNA sequencing data to identify gene expression changes. Microdissection and RNA isolation were performed at Loma Linda University. This research is crucial for understanding how spaceflight affects biological systems, particularly in the context of potential countermeasures for muscle and bone loss.
key_findings: Identified significant gene expression changes in the retina due to microgravity.
Comparison of spaceflight and ground control mice revealed distinct transcriptomic profiles.
Study provides insights into retinal health and potential countermeasures for spaceflight effects.

OSD-195.short_title: Impact of Bedrest on Muscle Gene Expression
OSD-195.short_summary: Study reveals effects of bedrest on human skeletal muscle genes.
OSD-195.summary: This study investigates the impact of 21 days of bedrest on gene expression in human skeletal muscle. Fourteen male participants underwent normoxic bedrest, with strict limitations on physical activity. The findings contribute to understanding how muscle unloading affects gene regulation. This research is part of a larger study examining various conditions of bedrest and ambulation.
OSD-195.description: The present study focuses on the effects of 21 days of sustained recumbence, or bedrest, on skeletal muscle gene expression in humans. Fourteen male subjects participated in normoxic bedrest, where they remained in a horizontal position without engaging in muscular exercise. This study is a substudy of the PlanHab-study, which also includes hypoxic conditions. During the bedrest period, subjects were allowed minimal movement and were prohibited from any form of exercise. Muscle samples were collected from the Vastus lateralis to analyze gene expression changes. The results provide insights into the biological responses of skeletal muscle to prolonged inactivity. Understanding these changes is crucial for developing countermeasures for muscle atrophy in various conditions.
key_findings: Significant alterations in gene expression observed after 21 days of bedrest.
Muscle unloading leads to specific changes in skeletal muscle biology.
Findings contribute to understanding muscle atrophy mechanisms.
Study highlights the importance of physical activity in gene regulation.
OSD-195.study_publication_title: PlanHab (Planetary Habitat Simulation): the combined and separate effects of 21 days bed rest and hypoxic confinement on human skeletal muscle miRNA expression

OSD-198.short_title: Impact of Bedrest and Hypoxia on miRNA
OSD-198.short_summary: Study investigates miRNA expression changes due to bedrest and hypoxia.
OSD-198.summary: This study explores the effects of bedrest and hypoxia on human skeletal muscle miRNA expression. Fourteen male participants underwent three different experimental conditions over a period of 21 days each. The findings provide insights into how these conditions influence muscle biology, which is crucial for understanding human health in extreme environments. The results may have implications for rehabilitation strategies and space travel.
OSD-198.description: The present study investigates the effects of 21 days of sustained recumbence (bedrest) and hypoxia on skeletal muscle microRNA expression in humans. Fourteen male subjects participated in three experimental campaigns: normoxic bedrest, hypoxic bedrest, and hypoxic ambulatory confinement. Each intervention lasted 21 days, separated by a 4-month wash-out period. During the bedrest interventions, subjects remained horizontal and were prohibited from muscular exercise. In contrast, during hypoxic ambulatory confinement, subjects could move freely within a hypoxic area while performing low-to-moderate-intensity exercise. Muscle samples were collected from the Vastus lateralis to analyze miRNA expression changes. This research is significant for understanding muscle adaptation in response to extreme conditions.
key_findings: Sustained bedrest alters miRNA expression in skeletal muscle.
Hypoxia further modifies miRNA profiles compared to normoxic conditions.
Combination of bedrest and hypoxia has unique effects on muscle biology.
Low-to-moderate exercise during hypoxia mitigates some negative effects.
OSD-198.study_publication_title: PlanHab (Planetary Habitat Simulation): the combined and separate effects of 21 days bed rest and hypoxic confinement on human skeletal muscle miRNA expression

OSD-199.short_summary: Investigating probiotic behavior in low shear modeled microgravity conditions.
OSD-199.summary: This study explores the effects of low shear modeled microgravity on Lactobacillus acidophilus ATCC 4356. It aims to determine how this probiotic strain behaves in spaceflight conditions. The findings suggest that the strain maintains its growth and survival characteristics, indicating potential benefits for astronauts. This research supports the use of probiotics as a countermeasure for microbiome and immune dysregulation in space.
OSD-199.description: The introduction of GRAS probiotic microbes into spaceflight food systems may provide a safe, non-invasive countermeasure to crew microbiome and immune dysregulation. This study specifically examines Lactobacillus acidophilus ATCC 4356 under low shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) conditions. By comparing growth and gene expression in LSMMG and control orientations, researchers aimed to assess the strain's stress tolerance and overall viability. Results showed no significant differences between the two environments, suggesting that L. acidophilus will perform similarly in space. This indicates that the strain could confer benefits observed on Earth even in microgravity. The findings pave the way for optimizing growth and strain selection for future space missions.
key_findings: Lactobacillus acidophilus ATCC 4356 shows no significant growth differences in microgravity conditions.
The strain maintains its stress tolerance and gene expression profiles in low shear modeled microgravity.
Probiotics may serve as effective countermeasures for astronaut health during spaceflight.
OSD-199.study_publication_title: Response of Lactobacillus acidophilus ATCC 4356 to low-shear modeled microgravity

OSD-200.short_summary: Study investigates microbial communities in bioaerosols aboard the ISS.
OSD-200.summary: This study evaluates the impact of microgravity on microbial communities in bioaerosols collected from the International Space Station (ISS). It focuses on how different particle size fractions influence these communities. Understanding these dynamics is crucial for assessing potential health risks to astronauts. The findings will contribute to the knowledge of microbial behavior in space environments.
OSD-200.description: Exposure to bioaerosols can pose significant health risks, especially in confined environments like the International Space Station (ISS). Unlike Earth, the ISS lacks gravitational settling, which alters the distribution and behavior of microbes. This study aims to identify and quantify the microbial communities present in various particle size fractions of bioaerosols collected on the ISS. By analyzing these communities, researchers hope to understand how microgravity affects microbial diversity and abundance. The results could inform strategies to mitigate health risks for astronauts during long-duration space missions. This research is vital for ensuring the safety and well-being of crew members in space.
key_findings: Identified diverse microbial communities in bioaerosols on the ISS.
Different particle size fractions showed varying microbial compositions.
Microgravity conditions significantly influence microbial behavior.
Potential health implications for astronauts due to bioaerosol exposure.
OSD-200.study_publication_title: Quantitative evaluation of bioaerosols in different particle size fractions collected on the International Space Station (ISS)

OSD-201.short_title: Effects of AOS on Mouse Immune Response
OSD-201.short_summary: Study explores how antiorthostatic suspension affects mouse responses to immunization.
OSD-201.summary: This study investigates the impact of antiorthostatic suspension (AOS) on the immune response of mice to tetanus toxoid and CpG. Mice were subjected to AOS or tail restraint for two weeks before receiving injections. The findings provide insights into how skeletal unloading influences immune function. This research has implications for understanding immune responses in microgravity environments.
OSD-201.description: The study focuses on the effects of antiorthostatic suspension (AOS) on the immune response in Mus musculus. Mice were either subjected to AOS or tail restraint for two weeks prior to receiving injections of saline, tetanus toxoid, or CpG. Following the injections, the mice underwent an additional two weeks of unloading before being sacrificed for analysis. The data generated from RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) will help elucidate the molecular changes associated with skeletal unloading and immune response. This research is particularly relevant for understanding how microgravity conditions, such as those experienced in space, may affect immune function. The findings could inform future studies on astronaut health and countermeasures for immune dysregulation in space. Overall, this study contributes valuable information to the field of space biology.
key_findings: AOS significantly alters immune response in mice.
RNA-Seq reveals gene expression changes post-injection.
Skeletal unloading impacts response to tetanus toxoid and CpG.
Study provides insights for future space health research.
OSD-201.study_publication_title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.

OSD-202.short_title: Impact of Low Dose Radiation on Mice
OSD-202.short_summary: Study investigates effects of low-dose radiation and microgravity on mouse brain and eye health.
OSD-202.summary: This study explores the effects of low-dose radiation and simulated microgravity on the brain and eye health of mice. Using a ground-based model, researchers subjected C57BL/6 mice to low-dose gamma radiation and hindlimb unloading for 21 days. The study aims to identify genomic signatures associated with these stressors. Findings could provide insights into the biological impacts of spaceflight conditions on mammalian systems.
OSD-202.description: The purpose of this study was to evaluate damage in the brain and eye of mice subjected to low-dose radiation and hindlimb unloading, simulating conditions of spaceflight. Mature female C57BL/6 mice received whole-body exposure to 0.04 Gy gamma radiation while undergoing anti-orthostatic tail suspension to mimic microgravity. Tissues were collected at various time points post-exposure to analyze the effects on multiple organ systems. The research employs an omics-based molecular phenotyping approach to characterize genomic responses. This study contributes to understanding how low-dose radiation and microgravity affect mammalian health. The findings may have implications for astronaut health during long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Identified genomic signatures linked to low-dose radiation exposure.
Demonstrated physiological stress responses in brain and eye tissues.
Established a model for studying spaceflight conditions on mammals.
Provided insights into potential health risks for astronauts.
OSD-202.study_publication_title: Mice Exposed to Combined Chronic Low-Dose Irradiation and Modeled Microgravity Develop Long-Term Neurological Sequelae

OSD-203.short_title: Impact of Low Dose Radiation on Mice
OSD-203.short_summary: Study investigates effects of low-dose radiation and microgravity on mouse retina.
OSD-203.summary: This study explores the effects of low-dose radiation and hindlimb unloading on the retina of mice. Using a ground-based model simulating spaceflight conditions, researchers assessed the impact of these factors on gene expression and epigenetic changes. The findings contribute to understanding how spaceflight-like conditions affect mammalian physiology.
OSD-203.description: The present study aimed to evaluate damage in the brain and eye of mice subjected to low-dose radiation and hindlimb unloading, simulating conditions of spaceflight. Mature, 6-month-old female C57BL/6 mice were exposed to 0.04 Gy of gamma-radiation while being hindlimb suspended for 21 days. This model mimicked the unloading, fluid shift, and physiological stress associated with microgravity. Tissues were collected at various time points: 7 days, 1 month, and 4 months post-exposure. The research utilized an omics-based molecular phenotyping approach to identify genomic signatures related to low-dose radiation and simulated microgravity. This study provides insights into the biological effects of spaceflight-like conditions on multiple organ systems.
key_findings: Identified significant changes in gene expression in retinal tissues.
Observed epigenetic modifications associated with low-dose radiation exposure.
Demonstrated the impact of simulated microgravity on physiological stress responses.
Provided a model for understanding spaceflight effects on mammalian health.

OSD-205.short_title: HsfA2's Role in Plant Spaceflight Adaptation
OSD-205.short_summary: Study reveals HsfA2's critical role in Arabidopsis adaptation to microgravity.
OSD-205.summary: This study investigates the role of the Heat Shock Factor A2 (HsfA2) in the adaptation of Arabidopsis thaliana to the microgravity environment of spaceflight. By comparing gene expression in wild type and HsfA2 knock-out cells aboard the ISS, researchers identified significant differences in physiological responses. The findings highlight the importance of HsfA2 in cellular adaptation mechanisms under space conditions.
OSD-205.description: The research focused on the Heat Shock Factor A2 (HsfA2), which is crucial for plant stress responses and homeostasis. Arabidopsis thaliana cell cultures, both wild type and HsfA2 knock-out, were sent to the ISS to study their adaptation to microgravity. After 10 days in space, microarray analysis revealed that HsfA2 KO cells utilized different gene expression profiles compared to wild type cells. This suggests that HsfA2 plays a significant role in the physiological adaptation to spaceflight. The study also identified specific genes necessary for achieving a spaceflight-adapted state. Notably, the research uncovered the involvement of endoplasmic reticulum stress and unfolded protein response in the HsfA2 KO cells. Overall, the findings provide insights into the genetic mechanisms underlying plant adaptation to extreme environments.
key_findings: HsfA2 is essential for physiological adaptation of Arabidopsis to microgravity.
Differential gene expression profiles were observed between wild type and HsfA2 KO cells.
Endoplasmic reticulum stress and unfolded protein response were prominent in HsfA2 KO cells.
Specific genes were identified as necessary for achieving a spaceflight-adapted state.
HsfA2 has roles in cell wall remodeling and starch biosynthesis under space conditions.
OSD-205.study_publication_title: HSFA2 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight

OSD-207.short_title: Gene and Protein Expression in Microgravity
OSD-207.short_summary: Exploring gene and protein responses in Drosophila under microgravity conditions.
OSD-207.summary: This study investigates the effects of microgravity on gene and protein expression in Drosophila melanogaster. By utilizing RNA sequencing and mass spectrometry, researchers analyzed samples from the heads of flies reared in space. The findings provide insights into how microgravity influences biological processes at the molecular level.
OSD-207.description: The research focuses on the omics analyses of RNA and protein extracted from the heads of adult Drosophila melanogaster that were reared in microgravity conditions. This study employs advanced techniques such as RNA sequencing and mass spectrometry to correlate gene and protein expression. Understanding these correlations is crucial for deciphering the biological impacts of spaceflight on living organisms. The results may have implications for future space missions and the health of astronauts. Additionally, this research contributes to the broader field of space biology by elucidating the molecular adaptations of organisms in altered gravitational environments. The study highlights the importance of model organisms like Drosophila in space research.
key_findings: Identified significant changes in gene expression due to microgravity.
Correlated protein expression patterns with RNA sequencing results.
Provided insights into molecular adaptations of Drosophila in space.

OSD-208.short_title: Comparing RNA-Seq and Microarray in Roots
OSD-208.short_summary: Study compares RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression in Arabidopsis root apex.
OSD-208.summary: This study investigates the gene expression in two zones of the Arabidopsis thaliana root apex using RNA sequencing and microarray techniques. It highlights the challenges of analyzing small root sections relevant to spaceflight. The findings reveal that both methods are effective, yet each has unique strengths in detecting different sets of genes. This research contributes to understanding how plants sense their environment, particularly in spaceflight conditions.
OSD-208.description: The root apex of Arabidopsis thaliana is crucial for environmental sensing but is challenging to analyze due to its small size. This study aimed to compare RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) and microarray techniques for gene expression analysis in two specific zones of the root apex. Zone 1 includes the root cap and meristematic zone, while Zone 2 encompasses the transition and elongation zones. The research found that both RNA-Seq and microarrays could effectively analyze these small samples. A total of 4180 differentially expressed genes were identified, with RNA-Seq revealing unique genes and novel transcriptionally active regions not detected by microarrays. Conversely, microarrays identified spaceflight-relevant genes that RNA-Seq missed. This study underscores the potential for enhancing techniques for analyzing small samples in spaceflight research.
key_findings: Both RNA-Seq and microarrays are applicable to small root samples.
4180 genes were differentially expressed between the two root zones.
RNA-Seq identified 771 unique genes and 19 novel transcriptionally active regions.
Microarrays detected spaceflight-relevant genes not found by RNA-Seq.
Single root tip subsections can be used for effective transcriptome analysis.
OSD-208.study_publication_title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight.

OSD-209.short_summary: Study reveals liver proteome alterations in mice after spaceflight and re-adaptation.
OSD-209.summary: This study investigates the impact of spaceflight and subsequent re-adaptation on the liver proteome of mice. After 30 days in space, mice showed no significant protein level changes compared to controls. However, those with a re-adaptation period exhibited notable alterations in their liver proteome. The findings suggest that re-adaptation may enhance gluconeogenesis and improve liver health indicators. This research provides insights into the metabolic adjustments required after space travel.
OSD-209.description: The study examines how prolonged spaceflight affects hepatic metabolism in mice, specifically focusing on the liver proteome. Mice were subjected to 30 days of spaceflight, followed by a 7-day re-adaptation period on Earth, and compared to control mice. Using shotgun mass spectrometry, researchers profiled the liver proteins to identify changes. While no significant differences were found between control and spaceflight groups, the re-adapted mice showed over a third of their protein levels altered. Notably, proteins linked to amino acid metabolism increased, indicating enhanced gluconeogenesis. Additionally, signs of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease decreased after re-adaptation. The study highlights the importance of monitoring metabolic changes post-spaceflight, particularly regarding glucose uptake and liver health.
key_findings: No significant protein level changes in spaceflight mice compared to controls.
Over a third of proteins altered in re-adapted mice livers.
Increased amino acid metabolism suggests enhanced gluconeogenesis post-re-adaptation.
Decreased signs of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease after 7 days on Earth.
Reconstitution of drug-metabolizing enzymes observed post-spaceflight.
OSD-209.study_publication_title: Re-Adaption on Earth after Spaceflights Affects the Mouse Liver Proteome

OSD-210.short_title: Assessing Cosmic Radiation Damage in Seeds
OSD-210.short_summary: Study investigates cosmic radiation effects on Arabidopsis thaliana seeds during a suborbital flight.
OSD-210.summary: This study explores the impact of cosmic radiation on Arabidopsis thaliana seeds through a suborbital flight experiment. Utilizing the CRESS payload system, researchers assessed genomic damage caused by Galactic Cosmic Radiation (GCR). The findings indicate significant differences in germination and mutation rates between irradiated and control seeds. This research provides insights into the biological effects of space radiation on plant life.
OSD-210.description: The Cosmic Ray Exposure Sequencing Science (CRESS) payload system was developed to evaluate the genomic impact of space radiation on seeds, specifically Arabidopsis thaliana. Launched as a secondary payload during a high-altitude balloon flight over Antarctica, the experiment aimed to investigate the biological effects of Galactic Cosmic Radiation (GCR). The payload was designed to CubeSat specifications and included four seed trays and twelve Solid-State Nuclear Track Detectors. After exposure, the irradiated seeds were recovered, sterilized, and grown for phenotypic screening. Results showed that seeds exposed to radiation had significantly reduced germination rates and increased mutation rates compared to non-irradiated controls. Notably, the mutation rate from the Brookhaven National Laboratory simulation was higher than that from the Antarctic exposure. Whole-genome sequencing revealed various structural variants in the genomes of the mutant plants, highlighting the genetic consequences of cosmic radiation.
key_findings: Irradiated seeds showed reduced germination rates compared to controls.
Higher somatic mutation rates were observed in seeds exposed to cosmic radiation.
Genomic analysis revealed structural variants in mutant plants.
The mutation rate was significantly higher in seeds from Brookhaven than those from Antarctica.
study_publication_title: Approaches for Surveying Cosmic Radiation Damage in Large Populations of Arabidopsis thaliana Seeds
x96 Antarctic Balloons and Particle Beams

OSD-211.short_summary: Study reveals effects of radiation and unloading on mouse spleen transcriptomes.
OSD-211.summary: This study investigates the transcriptional changes in mouse spleens subjected to chronic low-dose radiation and hindlimb unloading. Utilizing a ground-based model to simulate spaceflight conditions, the research provides insights into how these stressors affect gene expression. RNA sequencing was performed on spleens collected after treatment, revealing significant alterations in transcription. The findings contribute to understanding the biological impacts of spaceflight-like conditions on mammalian physiology.
OSD-211.description: The purpose of this study was to evaluate transcriptional changes in mouse spleens using a ground-based model for spaceflight. This model includes prolonged unloading and low-dose irradiation to simulate the radiation environment of spaceflight. Specifically, low-dose-rate gamma-radiation was delivered to 6-month old female C57BL/6J mice using 57Co plates. Anti-orthostatic tail suspension was employed to model the unloading and physiological stress aspects of microgravity. Mice were subjected to hindlimb suspension and/or irradiation for 21 days. After treatment, the mice were euthanized, and spleens were collected 7 days later. RNA sequencing data was generated to assess the transcriptional changes in these spleens, providing valuable insights into the biological effects of spaceflight-like conditions.
key_findings: Significant transcriptional changes observed in spleens due to radiation and unloading.
Low-dose gamma-radiation mimicked spaceflight radiation exposure.
Hindlimb unloading induced physiological stress similar to microgravity.
RNA sequencing revealed altered gene expression patterns.
Findings enhance understanding of spaceflight impacts on mammalian health.

OSD-212.short_summary: Study reveals significant shifts in gut microbiota and metabolism in space.
OSD-212.summary: This study investigates the impact of spaceflight on the gut microbiome of mice. It highlights reproducible changes in microbial composition and host metabolism under space conditions. The findings contribute to understanding how spaceflight affects biological systems.
OSD-212.description: Conducted as part of a NASA-funded initiative, this research focuses on the gastrointestinal microbiota of mice during spaceflight. The study utilized 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing to analyze fecal samples collected from mice. Data were compared with previous studies from shuttle missions and ground-based radiation experiments. The results indicate significant shifts in microbial populations and metabolic processes due to the unique conditions of spaceflight. Understanding these changes is crucial for future long-duration space missions. The study provides insights into the interplay between microbiota and host health in microgravity environments.
key_findings: Significant shifts in gut microbiome composition observed during spaceflight.
Alterations in host metabolism linked to changes in microbial populations.
Data compared with previous shuttle missions and ground studies.
Findings enhance understanding of biological responses to space conditions.
OSD-212.study_publication_title: Reproducible changes in the gut microbiome suggest a shift in microbial and host metabolism during spaceflight.

OSD-213.short_title: Gene Expression in Arabidopsis in Microgravity
OSD-213.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in Arabidopsis thaliana under microgravity conditions.
OSD-213.summary: This study investigates the effects of microgravity on the gene expression of Arabidopsis thaliana cell cultures. Conducted aboard the Shenzhou 8 spacecraft, the experiment lasted for five days. The findings provide insights into how spaceflight conditions influence plant biology. Understanding these changes is crucial for future space exploration and potential agricultural applications in space.
OSD-213.description: Arabidopsis thaliana wild type cell cultures were subjected to a unique environment during a five-day space flight on the Shenzhou 8 mission. The primary goal was to identify gene expression changes related to microgravity exposure. By utilizing DNA microarray technology, researchers were able to analyze the entire genome for alterations in gene activity. The results shed light on the molecular mechanisms plants use to adapt to space conditions. This research not only enhances our understanding of plant biology in extreme environments but also has implications for future space missions. The findings may inform strategies for growing plants in space, which is essential for long-duration human spaceflight. Overall, this study contributes valuable data to the field of astrobiology and space agriculture.
key_findings: Significant changes in gene expression observed in microgravity.
Altered stress response pathways identified in Arabidopsis.
Insights into plant adaptation mechanisms in space environments.
Potential implications for space agriculture and sustainability.
OSD-213.study_publication_title: A Whole-Genome Microarray Study of Arabidopsis thaliana Semisolid Callus Cultures Exposed to Microgravity and Nonmicrogravity Related Spaceflight Conditions for 5 Days on Board of Shenzhou 8

OSD-214.short_title: Effects of AOS on Mouse Immune Response
OSD-214.short_summary: Study investigates the impact of antiorthostatic suspension on mouse immune responses.
OSD-214.summary: This study examines how antiorthostatic suspension (AOS) affects the immune response in mice. Specifically, it focuses on the transcriptomic changes in bone marrow following exposure to tetanus toxoid and CpG. The findings contribute to understanding the effects of skeletal unloading on immune function. This research is crucial for insights into how microgravity environments may influence immune responses.
OSD-214.description: The data were collected from Mus musculus subjected to antiorthostatic suspension (AOS) for two weeks, followed by an injection with saline, tetanus toxoid, and CpG. A control group underwent tail restraint without unloading. After an additional two weeks of unloading, the mice were sacrificed for analysis. The primary focus of this dataset is on the bone marrow transcriptomic response. This study provides valuable insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying immune responses in altered gravitational conditions. The spleen data related to this study can be found in a separate dataset (GLDS-201). Understanding these responses is essential for future space missions and health management in microgravity.
key_findings: AOS significantly alters bone marrow transcriptomic profiles.
Immune response varies with exposure to tetanus toxoid and CpG.
Skeletal unloading impacts gene expression related to immune function.
OSD-214.study_publication_title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice

OSD-215.short_title: HARV Replication of Bacillus subtilis Samples
OSD-215.short_summary: This study replicates spaceflight transcriptome changes in Bacillus subtilis.
OSD-215.summary: This study investigates the transcriptome changes in Bacillus subtilis during spaceflight by replicating conditions on Earth. Using High Aspect Ratio Vessels (HARVs), researchers aimed to mimic the growth conditions of the BRIC-21 spaceflight mission. RNA sequencing was performed to analyze gene expression differences. The findings will help validate HARVs as a model for future spaceflight experiments.
OSD-215.description: Previous research has shown that Bacillus subtilis exhibits altered gene expression profiles during spaceflight. This study sought to replicate those changes using HARVs, which provide a controlled environment for bacterial growth. B. subtilis spores were cultivated under the same conditions as the BRIC-21 mission, and RNA was extracted for sequencing. The resulting data was analyzed for differential gene expression. By comparing the HARV results to those from the spaceflight mission, the study assesses the effectiveness of HARVs as a terrestrial model for space conditions. This research contributes to our understanding of microbial behavior in space and the potential implications for long-duration space missions. The outcomes may inform future studies on microbial life in extraterrestrial environments.
key_findings: HARV conditions successfully replicated growth parameters of the BRIC-21 mission.
Differential gene expression was observed in HARV samples compared to ground controls.
HARVs may serve as a reliable model for studying spaceflight effects on bacteria.
Findings support the hypothesis of altered transcriptome profiles during spaceflight.
OSD-215.study_publication_title: Comparisons of Transcriptome Profiles from Bacillus subtilis Cells Grown in Space versus High Aspect Ratio Vessel (HARV) Clinostats Reveal a Low Degree of Concordance

OSD-216.short_title: HARV Replication of Bacillus subtilis Spaceflight
OSD-216.short_summary: This study replicates Bacillus subtilis transcriptome changes during spaceflight using HARVs.
OSD-216.summary: This study investigates the transcriptome changes of Bacillus subtilis during spaceflight by replicating conditions using High Aspect Ratio Vessels (HARVs). RNA sequencing was performed on samples grown in HARVs to identify differentially expressed genes. The findings aim to validate HARVs as a reliable model for spaceflight experiments. By comparing the results with previous spaceflight data, the study enhances our understanding of microbial behavior in space.
OSD-216.description: Previous research has shown that Bacillus subtilis exhibits altered transcriptome profiles during spaceflight compared to ground samples. This study aimed to replicate those changes using High Aspect Ratio Vessels (HARVs) under controlled conditions. Spores of B. subtilis were cultivated in HARVs following the same protocols as the BRIC-23 spaceflight mission. RNA was extracted from these samples and subjected to RNA sequencing for differential expression analysis. The differentially expressed genes identified in the HARV samples were then compared to those from the BRIC-23 mission. This comparison helps assess the accuracy of HARVs as a model for simulating spaceflight conditions. The results contribute to a deeper understanding of microbial responses to space environments.
key_findings: HARVs successfully replicated growth conditions of the BRIC-23 mission.
Differentially expressed genes were identified in HARV samples.
Comparison with BRIC-23 data validated HARVs as a model.
Study enhances understanding of microbial behavior in space.
OSD-216.study_publication_title: Comparisons of Transcriptome Profiles from Bacillus subtilis Cells Grown in Space versus High Aspect Ratio Vessel (HARV) Clinostats Reveal a Low Degree of Concordance

OSD-217.short_summary: Study reveals epigenetic regulation in Arabidopsis during spaceflight.
OSD-217.summary: This study investigates the epigenetic regulation of Arabidopsis thaliana grown aboard the International Space Station. It focuses on understanding the molecular mechanisms behind altered growth habits observed in plants during spaceflight. By employing whole genome bisulfite sequencing and RNA sequencing, the research aims to provide insights into how extraterrestrial environments affect plant biology. The findings will contribute to NASA's goals for future space exploration.
OSD-217.description: The research explores how Arabidopsis thaliana adapts to the unique conditions of spaceflight, particularly aboard the International Space Station. While the plants do not show abnormal structures, their growth habits are notably altered, prompting an investigation into the underlying molecular mechanisms. The study utilizes advanced molecular and genetic tools to examine changes in root structure, growth patterns, and cell wall remodeling. By characterizing the methylome and gene expression profiles, the research aims to enhance our understanding of plant responses to extraterrestrial environments. This knowledge is crucial for defining the impacts of spaceflight on biological systems. Ultimately, the findings will support NASA's future endeavors in space exploration.
key_findings: Arabidopsis thaliana exhibits altered growth habits in space.
Molecular mechanisms of epigenetic regulation were identified.
Whole genome bisulfite sequencing revealed changes in methylation patterns.
RNA sequencing provided insights into gene expression alterations.
Study advances understanding of plant biology in extraterrestrial environments.
OSD-217.study_publication_title: Epigenomics in an extraterrestrial environment: organ-specific alteration of DNA methylation and gene expression elicited by spaceflight in Arabidopsis thaliana.

OSD-218.short_title: Genetic Influence on Plant Growth in Space
OSD-218.short_summary: Study reveals how genetic background affects plant development in space versus on Earth.
OSD-218.summary: This study investigates the developmental differences of Arabidopsis thaliana plants grown on the International Space Station (ISS) compared to those on Earth. It highlights the significant role of genetic background in shaping plant responses to spaceflight conditions. The findings suggest that plants exhibit distinct gene expression patterns depending on their environment and age. Notably, the study reveals that spaceflight influences physiological processes differently than terrestrial conditions.
OSD-218.description: The research focuses on two genotypes of Arabidopsis thaliana, Col-0 and WS, examining their development from 4 to 8 days old in both space and ground environments. It was found that Col-0 plants in orbit displayed a deficit in wax and suberin production compared to their ground counterparts. Additionally, the study noted that the root system development genes were overexpressed in 8-day-old plants on the ground, indicating a more pronounced developmental gap than in space. Interestingly, WS plants showed unique overexpression of photosynthesis-related genes in their 4-day-old roots in space, a response not observed on Earth. These findings underscore the importance of genetic background in plant adaptation to novel growth environments like the ISS. Overall, the study provides valuable insights into how microgravity affects plant development at the molecular level.
key_findings: Col-0 plants showed different gene expression in space compared to ground.
WS plants uniquely overexpressed photosynthesis genes in space.
Developmental strategies differ significantly between space and ground environments.
Root development gaps were smaller in space than on Earth.

OSD-220.short_title: Methylation Changes in Arabidopsis Under Microgravity
OSD-220.short_summary: This study explores DNA methylation in Arabidopsis seedlings in space.
OSD-220.summary: This research investigates the impact of microgravity on DNA methylation patterns in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings. By utilizing whole genome bisulfite sequencing, the study provides insights into the epigenetic modifications that occur in response to spaceflight conditions. The findings contribute to our understanding of how plants adapt to altered gravitational environments. This work is significant for future space agriculture and plant biology.
OSD-220.description: DNA methylation is a crucial epigenetic modification that influences various biological functions. While many studies have focused on different plant species, research on global DNA methylation patterns in microgravity has been limited. This study maps the changes in the methylome of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings exposed to microgravity during the SJ-10 mission. Using whole genome bisulfite sequencing, the researchers achieved single-base resolution in their analysis. The results reveal significant alterations in methylation patterns, providing insights into plant adaptation mechanisms in space. Understanding these changes is vital for future space missions and the potential for growing plants in extraterrestrial environments. This research lays the groundwork for further exploration of plant biology in microgravity.
key_findings: Identified significant changes in DNA methylation patterns in Arabidopsis seedlings.
Utilized whole genome bisulfite sequencing for high-resolution analysis.
Demonstrated the impact of microgravity on epigenetic modifications.
Contributed to understanding plant adaptation to space environments.
OSD-220.study_publication_title: Single-base resolution methylome analysis shows epigenetic changes in Arabidopsis seedlings exposed to microgravity spaceflight conditions on board the SJ-10 recoverable satellite

OSD-222.short_summary: Study of cerebellum gene expression in space-flown mice.
OSD-222.summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight on gene expression in the cerebellum of mice. Mice were flown aboard the STS-135 mission and their cerebellums were analyzed after returning to Earth. The findings contribute to understanding how microgravity affects neurological functions.
OSD-222.description: In this study, Mus musculus specimens were sent into space as part of the STS-135 mission. Upon their return, cerebellum tissues were collected within 3-4 hours and immediately snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen to preserve their integrity. The samples were then shipped to the UCI Genomics High Throughput Facility for comprehensive DNA microarray analysis. This research aims to elucidate the molecular changes that occur in the cerebellum due to the unique conditions of spaceflight. Understanding these changes is crucial for assessing the impacts of long-duration space missions on mammalian physiology. The results may also provide insights into potential countermeasures for future human space exploration.
key_findings: Identification of gene expression changes in cerebellum due to microgravity.
Insights into neurological adaptations in space.
Potential implications for long-duration human spaceflight.

OSD-223.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Arabidopsis Signaling
OSD-223.short_summary: Study reveals how spaceflight affects plant signaling mechanisms.
OSD-223.summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight on transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana plants with altered signaling pathways. Conducted aboard the International Space Station, the research compares the transcript profiles of wild type and genetically modified plants. The findings enhance our understanding of plant adaptation to microgravity and other space-related challenges.
OSD-223.description: The research focuses on the molecular mechanisms that enable plants to sense and adapt to the unique conditions of space. The experiment, titled 'Plant Signaling in Microgravity,' utilized transgenic Arabidopsis plants that express a specific enzyme affecting inositol signaling. These plants were grown under controlled conditions on the ISS, allowing for a comparison between microgravity and normal gravity environments. RNA sequencing was performed on samples collected from both shoot and root tissues. The results highlight significant differences in gene expression between the wild type and transgenic plants. Understanding these differences is crucial for developing plants that can thrive in space. This study contributes valuable insights into plant biology and potential applications for future space missions.
key_findings: Transgenic Arabidopsis plants show altered responses to environmental stimuli in microgravity.
RNA sequencing reveals conserved and altered regulatory mechanisms in gene expression.
The study enhances understanding of plant adaptation to spaceflight conditions.
study_publication_title: Uncovering Transcriptional Responses to Fractional Gravity in Arabidopsis Roots
Conserved plant transcriptional responses to microgravity from two consecutive spaceflight experiments

OSD-224.short_title: Microbial Profiles from the International Space Station
OSD-224.short_summary: Study reveals microbial diversity aboard the ISS and its implications for human health.
OSD-224.summary: This study investigates the microbial composition of the International Space Station (ISS) environment. By analyzing whole metagenomes from air filter and dust samples, researchers assessed the potential impact of these microbes on human health. The findings highlight significant differences between ISS and terrestrial cleanroom environments. This research is crucial for ensuring astronaut safety and mission success.
OSD-224.description: The microbial composition of the International Space Station (ISS) is of critical interest due to its potential impact on human health and mission success. This study examined the whole metagenome of ISS microbes at both species and gene-level resolution. Air filter and dust samples were collected from the ISS and compared to samples from a terrestrial cleanroom environment. The analysis focused on DNA from both total and viable microbial populations. Researchers quantified microbial genes related to human health, including antimicrobial resistance and virulence factors. Understanding the microbial diversity aboard the ISS is essential for developing effective countermeasures for astronaut health. This research contributes valuable insights into the unique challenges posed by the space environment.
key_findings: Identified diverse microbial communities aboard the ISS.
Compared ISS microbial profiles with terrestrial cleanroom samples.
Quantified genes related to antimicrobial resistance and virulence.
Highlighted potential health risks for astronauts.
Provided insights for future space mission planning.
OSD-224.study_publication_title: Whole metagenome profiles of particulates collected from the International Space Station.

OSD-225.short_title: Soleus Muscle Expression in Simulated Spaceflight
OSD-225.short_summary: Study reveals transcriptional changes in rat soleus muscle under simulated spaceflight conditions.
OSD-225.summary: This study investigates the effects of simulated spaceflight on the expression profile of rat soleus muscle. Using DNA microarray technology, researchers examined transcriptional changes associated with muscle atrophy induced by microgravity and low-dose radiation. The findings contribute to understanding the unique challenges astronauts face regarding muscle health during space missions. Insights from this research may help develop effective countermeasures against muscle atrophy in space.
OSD-225.description: Spaceflight poses significant risks to skeletal muscle health, particularly atrophy, which can affect astronauts during missions. This study focuses on understanding the transcriptional changes in the soleus muscle of Rattus norvegicus under conditions simulating spaceflight. By employing two ground-based models that replicate microgravity and low radiation environments, researchers aimed to differentiate spaceflight-induced muscle atrophy from other forms. The use of DNA microarray technology allowed for a comprehensive analysis of gene expression changes. The results highlight the unique impact of cosmic rays in space on muscle health. This research is crucial for developing countermeasures to mitigate muscle atrophy in astronauts. Continued exploration in this area is essential for future long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Transcriptional changes in soleus muscle were identified under simulated spaceflight conditions.
The study differentiated spaceflight-induced muscle atrophy from other forms of atrophy.
Low-dose radiation combined with microgravity significantly affects muscle gene expression.
Findings may inform countermeasure strategies for astronauts' muscle health.
OSD-225.study_publication_title: Mimic microgravity effect on muscle transcriptome under ionizing radiation.

OSD-227.short_title: Impact of Muscle Unloading on Gene Expression
OSD-227.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes due to muscle unloading.
OSD-227.summary: This study investigates the effects of acute muscle unloading on gene expression in mice. Using hind-limb suspension, researchers analyzed changes in mRNA profiles of the soleus and gastrocnemius muscles. The findings highlight significant physiological changes associated with muscle atrophy and metabolic inflexibility. This research contributes to understanding muscle response to unloading conditions.
OSD-227.description: The study explores gene expression alterations caused by acute skeletal muscle unloading, which can lead to muscle atrophy and metabolic inflexibility. Male ICR mice underwent hind-limb suspension (HLS) treatment to simulate muscle unloading. Researchers utilized Agilent Whole Mouse Genome Oligo Microarrays to assess mRNA expression profiles in the soleus and gastrocnemius muscles. The comparison was made between freely ambulating control mice and those subjected to 24 hours of HLS. Results indicate substantial changes in gene expression linked to muscle function and energy metabolism. This research is crucial for understanding muscle adaptation in unloading scenarios, which has implications for space travel and rehabilitation.
key_findings: Acute muscle unloading leads to significant gene expression changes.
Muscle atrophy and fibre-type switching were observed.
Metabolic inflexibility was induced by hind-limb suspension.
Soleus and gastrocnemius muscles showed distinct expression profiles.
OSD-227.study_publication_title: Muscle unloading-induced metabolic remodeling is associated with acute alterations in PPARdelta and UCP-3 expression

OSD-228.short_title: Effects of Hindlimb Suspension on Muscle
OSD-228.short_summary: Study investigates muscle response to hindlimb suspension and reloading in mice.
OSD-228.summary: This study explores the impact of hindlimb suspension and subsequent reloading on the soleus muscle of C57Bl/6 mice. By examining various experimental groups, researchers aimed to understand muscle atrophy and recovery processes. The findings contribute to our knowledge of muscle physiology and potential rehabilitation strategies following disuse. This research is particularly relevant for understanding muscle health in both terrestrial and space environments.
OSD-228.description: The study investigates the effects of hindlimb suspension on the soleus muscle of C57Bl/6 mice, a model commonly used in muscle research. Mice were divided into several experimental groups, including a control group and groups subjected to hindlimb suspension for varying durations. The suspension lasted for 7 days, followed by reloading periods of either 1 or 7 days. This design allows for a comprehensive analysis of muscle atrophy during disuse and the recovery process upon reloading. The results are expected to shed light on the mechanisms of muscle adaptation and the potential for therapeutic interventions. Understanding these processes is crucial for developing strategies to mitigate muscle loss in various conditions, including spaceflight.
key_findings: Hindlimb suspension leads to significant muscle atrophy.
Reloading after suspension promotes muscle recovery.
Duration of reloading impacts recovery outcomes.
Control mice maintained muscle integrity without atrophy.
study_publication_title: Transcriptional reprogramming and ultrastructure during atrophy and recovery of mouse soleus muscle
Transcriptional profiling of tissue plasticity: role of shifts in gene expression and technical limitations

OSD-232.short_summary: Study investigates cartilage changes in mice after 30 days in microgravity.
OSD-232.summary: This study explores how murine cartilage responds to microgravity conditions experienced during spaceflight. Mice were flown for 30 days on the BION-M1 mission, allowing researchers to analyze changes in their articular and sterno-costal cartilages. The study utilized microarray technology to assess gene expression and histological techniques to evaluate proteoglycan loss. The findings provide insights into the biological effects of microgravity on skeletal tissues.
OSD-232.description: Articular and sterno-costal cartilages were isolated from skeletally mature mice that participated in the BION-M1 mission, where they experienced 30 days of microgravity. The research aimed to characterize the impact of this environment on cartilage health and integrity. Histological analysis revealed changes in proteoglycan content, while gene expression was assessed using Affymetrix gene arrays. These methodologies allowed for a comprehensive understanding of the molecular and structural alterations in cartilage due to microgravity. The results have implications for understanding skeletal health in astronauts and potential countermeasures for spaceflight-related bone and cartilage loss. This study contributes to the broader knowledge of how microgravity affects biological systems.
key_findings: Significant proteoglycan loss observed in murine cartilage after microgravity exposure.
Altered gene expression profiles identified using microarray technology.
Findings suggest potential risks for skeletal health in astronauts during long-duration space missions.
OSD-232.study_publication_title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity

OSD-233.short_title: Genomic Changes in Aspergillus nidulans in Space
OSD-233.short_summary: Study reveals how space conditions affect Aspergillus nidulans genomics and metabolomics.
OSD-233.summary: This study investigates the effects of International Space Station (ISS) conditions on the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans. It highlights significant genomic, proteomic, and metabolomic changes observed in both wild-type and mutant strains. The findings provide insights into how this organism adapts to the unique environment of space.
OSD-233.description: The research presents the first comprehensive characterization of Aspergillus nidulans under spaceflight conditions. Whole genome sequencing indicated specific genomic alterations due to the ISS environment, particularly in the laeA gene associated with secondary metabolite production. Notably, the study observed differential protein expression related to stress response and metabolism. The wild-type strain showed reduced prenyl xanthone production, while mutant strains exhibited increased production of asperthecin. These results suggest that space conditions can significantly influence fungal metabolism and gene expression. Understanding these adaptations could have implications for future space missions and biotechnological applications.
key_findings: ISS conditions altered the genome of Aspergillus nidulans in specific regions.
Loss of the laeA stop codon was induced in strain CW12001.
Differential protein expression was noted in stress response and metabolism.
Prenyl xanthone production decreased in wild-type, while asperthecin increased in mutants.
OSD-233.study_publication_title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans

OSD-235.short_title: RNA-Seq Analysis of Mouse Liver Preservation
OSD-235.short_summary: Study investigates RNA sequencing effects of various tissue preservation methods in mice.
OSD-235.summary: This study explores the impact of different euthanasia and tissue preservation protocols on gene expression in mouse liver samples. By utilizing RNA sequencing, researchers aim to identify how these factors may confound data analysis in spaceflight conditions. The findings will help improve sample preservation techniques for future NASA missions involving rodent research.
OSD-235.description: To ensure accurate gene expression analysis in spaceflight studies, high-quality sample preservation is crucial. The study involved 20-21 week-old female C57BL/6J mice, euthanized using different protocols and preserved under various conditions. RNA was extracted from liver samples to assess the effects of these methods on gene expression. The results will provide insights into optimizing preservation techniques for future experiments in microgravity. Understanding these factors is vital for accurate data interpretation in spaceflight research. This study ultimately aims to enhance the reliability of biological data collected during space missions.

Using RNA sequencing, researchers aimed to identify how these factors might confound data analysis in spaceflight studies. The findings will inform best practices for sample preservation in future NASA missions.

This study builds on previous research by examining multiple euthanasia and preservation methods used in NASA's Rodent Research missions. Specifically, it investigates the effects of euthanasia protocols, carcass preservation techniques, and tissue preservation methods on gene expression in the quadriceps of C57BL/6J mice. Mice were euthanized using different methods and their quadriceps were preserved using various techniques. RNA was extracted and analyzed through RNA sequencing to generate gene expression profiles. The results will help determine the best practices for preserving samples in spaceflight conditions, ensuring reliable data for future studies.
