OSD-237.short_title: Transcriptomic Changes in Mouse Skin Study
OSD-237.short_summary: This study investigates skin transcriptional changes in mice under simulated spaceflight conditions.
OSD-237.summary: This research explores the effects of chronic low-dose radiation and hindlimb unloading on mouse skin. Using a ground-based model for spaceflight, the study evaluates transcriptional changes through RNA sequencing. The findings provide insights into the biological responses of skin to conditions mimicking spaceflight. This work contributes to understanding how spaceflight may impact mammalian physiology.
OSD-237.description: The purpose of this study was to evaluate transcriptional changes in mouse skin using a ground-based model for spaceflight. This model includes prolonged unloading and low-dose irradiation. Low-dose-rate gamma-radiation was delivered to 6-month old female C57BL/6J mice using 57Co plates (0.04 Gy) to simulate the radiation environment of spaceflight. Anti-orthostatic tail suspension was used to model the unloading, fluid shift, and physiological stress aspects of the microgravity component of spaceflight. Mice were hindlimb suspended and/or irradiated for 21 days. After treatment, mice were euthanized, and dorsal skin was collected 7 days later. RNA sequencing data was generated to assess transcriptional changes in these skin samples, providing valuable insights into the biological effects of spaceflight-like conditions.
key_findings: Chronic low-dose radiation alters gene expression in mouse skin.
Hindlimb unloading impacts skin transcriptional profiles.
Combined effects of radiation and unloading reveal unique transcriptional responses.
RNA sequencing provides a comprehensive view of skin adaptations.

OSD-238.short_summary: Study investigates RNA changes in mice during spaceflight.
OSD-238.summary: This study explores the transcriptomic effects of spaceflight on mice. Specifically, it examines how microgravity and dietary supplements influence gene expression in dorsal skin. The research aims to enhance our understanding of the gut environment and immune response in space. Findings will contribute to future space missions and health management of astronauts.
OSD-238.description: The JAXA MHU-2 mission aimed to understand the effects of spaceflight on the gut microbiota and immune system through multi-omics analysis. Twelve male C57BL/6J mice were flown on the ISS for 30 days, with half exposed to microgravity and the other half to simulated 1g. Each group was further divided based on diet, receiving either standard chow or fructo-oligosaccharides (FOS) supplements. After returning, mice were euthanized, and their dorsal skin was collected for RNA sequencing. This study provides insights into how spaceflight conditions and dietary changes affect gene expression. The results could inform dietary strategies for astronauts during long-duration missions. Overall, the research highlights the importance of understanding biological responses to space environments.
key_findings: RNA sequencing revealed significant gene expression changes in mice exposed to microgravity.
Dietary fructo-oligosaccharides influenced immune-related gene expression.
Differences were noted between microgravity and simulated 1g conditions.
Findings may inform dietary recommendations for astronauts.
Study enhances understanding of spaceflight's impact on mammalian biology.

The research aims to enhance our understanding of biological responses to space environments.
OSD-239.description: The JAXA MHU-2 mission aimed to investigate the effects of spaceflight on the gut environment and immune system through multi-omics analysis. Twelve male C57BL/6J mice were housed in microgravity for 30 days, with a control group exposed to simulated 1g. The study examined the impact of fructo-oligosaccharides (FOS) in the diet on gut health and immune function. After the mission, mice were euthanized, and femoral skin samples were collected for RNA sequencing. This analysis focused on understanding gene expression changes due to spaceflight and dietary interventions. The results could inform future studies on astronaut health and the biological implications of long-duration space missions. Overall, the research highlights the importance of diet in mitigating the effects of microgravity on biological systems.
key_findings: Microgravity alters gene expression in mouse skin.

OSD-240.short_title: RNA Sequencing of Spaceflown Mice Skin
OSD-240.short_summary: Study investigates gene expression in mice skin after spaceflight.
OSD-240.summary: This study explores the transcriptional changes in the dorsal skin of mice that were flown on the RR-5 mission. It aims to understand the effects of spaceflight on gene expression and the potential protective effects of NELL-1 treatment. The research involved RNA sequencing of samples collected from both spaceflown and ground control mice. Findings may provide insights into the biological impacts of microgravity on mammalian skin. This work contributes to our understanding of spaceflight's effects on health.
OSD-240.description: The Rodent Research-5 (RR-5) study focused on evaluating bone loss in mice during spaceflight and the efficacy of NELL-1 treatment in mitigating this loss. A cohort of forty 30-week-old female BALB/cAnNTac mice was flown to the International Space Station (ISS) and housed in a specialized habitat. Half of the mice received NELL-1 treatment, while the other half received a vehicle control. After 30 days in space, twenty mice were returned to Earth for further analysis. RNA was extracted from preserved dorsal skin samples of both experimental and control groups. The study utilized RNA sequencing to assess gene expression changes due to spaceflight. This research is significant for understanding the molecular responses of mammals to microgravity and potential countermeasures for spaceflight-induced health issues.
key_findings: NELL-1 treatment may influence gene expression in spaceflown mice.
RNA sequencing revealed significant transcriptional changes in dorsal skin.
Study provides insights into the effects of microgravity on mammalian biology.
Findings could inform future countermeasures for spaceflight health risks.

OSD-241.short_summary: Study investigates gene expression in mice during spaceflight and NELL-1 treatment.
OSD-241.summary: This study explores the effects of spaceflight on gene expression in mice, specifically focusing on femoral skin samples. Mice were treated with a modified NELL-1 molecule to assess its potential in preventing bone loss. RNA sequencing was performed on samples from both spaceflown and ground control mice. The findings aim to enhance our understanding of bone health in microgravity environments.
OSD-241.description: The Rodent Research-5 (RR-5) study aimed to evaluate the impact of spaceflight on bone loss in mice and the efficacy of NELL-1 treatment. A cohort of forty BALB/cAnNTac mice was flown to the ISS, where they received either NELL-1 or a vehicle control treatment. After two weeks in space, selected mice were returned to Earth for recovery and further analysis. RNA was extracted from femoral skin samples to investigate transcriptional changes. The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying bone health in microgravity. Understanding these changes is crucial for developing countermeasures against bone loss in astronauts. The results could have implications for both space exploration and terrestrial health.

A group of male C57BL/6J mice was launched to the International Space Station (ISS) for 33 days. After their return, the livers were preserved for RNA sequencing to analyze gene expression changes. This research is crucial for understanding the biological impacts of microgravity on mammalian systems. The results could inform countermeasures for astronaut health in future missions.

OSD-243.short_title: Muscle Atrophy Study in Spaceflight Mice
OSD-243.short_summary: This study investigates muscle atrophy in mice during spaceflight.
OSD-243.summary: The RR-6 study focused on understanding muscle atrophy in mice exposed to microgravity. It utilized RNA sequencing to analyze dorsal skin samples from mice flown on the SpaceX-13 mission. The research aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel therapeutic to mitigate muscle wasting. The findings contribute to our understanding of how spaceflight affects mammalian biology.
OSD-243.description: The Rodent Research-6 (RR-6) study aimed to evaluate muscle atrophy in mice during spaceflight and test a novel therapeutic to mitigate muscle wasting. A cohort of forty female C57BL/6NTac mice underwent either sham operations or implantation of a drug delivery system before being launched on SpaceX-13. They were maintained in microgravity for varying durations, with some returned live to Earth. RNA sequencing was performed on dorsal skin samples from several groups, including flight and ground control mice. The study's design included multiple baseline and control groups to ensure robust data collection. This research provides insights into the biological impacts of microgravity on mammalian physiology, particularly regarding muscle health. The results may inform future therapeutic strategies for muscle atrophy in space and on Earth.
key_findings: RNA sequencing revealed significant transcriptional changes in dorsal skin of mice in microgravity.
The study identified potential biomarkers for muscle atrophy related to spaceflight.
The therapeutic intervention showed promise in mitigating muscle wasting effects.
Comparative analysis between flight and ground control groups highlighted the impact of microgravity.
OSD-243.study_publication_title: Counteracting Muscle Atrophy on Earth and in Space via Nanofluidics Delivery of Formoterol

OSD-250.description: The Rodent Research-9 (RR-9) mission utilized male C57BL/6J mice to explore health challenges faced by astronauts, particularly visual impairment and joint tissue degradation. Mice were launched to the International Space Station (ISS) for 33 days, after which they were returned to Earth for analysis. Fecal samples were collected from various control groups, including Basal, Ground, and Vivarium controls, as well as two cohort controls. OSD-251.short_title: Arabidopsis thaliana Response to Space Gravity
OSD-251.short_summary: Study explores plant responses to fractional gravity during spaceflight under blue light.
OSD-251.summary: This study investigates how Arabidopsis thaliana responds to varying gravity levels during spaceflight. The research was conducted on the International Space Station, where seedlings were exposed to different gravity conditions and blue light. RNA sequencing was performed to analyze gene expression changes. The findings contribute to understanding plant growth in extraterrestrial environments.
OSD-251.description: As space agencies aim for missions to extraterrestrial bodies with reduced gravity, understanding plant responses is crucial for life support systems. This study focuses on Arabidopsis thaliana, which was grown under microgravity and partial gravity conditions on the ISS. The seedlings were subjected to blue light stimulation for 48 hours after germination. RNA was extracted from samples for RNA sequencing to analyze gene expression. The HISAT2-Stringtie-DESeq pipeline was utilized for transcriptomic analysis. Differentially expressed genes were characterized using the GEDI tool and Gene Ontology enrichment. These insights will help inform future space missions involving plant cultivation.
key_findings: Differential gene expression observed under varying gravity levels.
Blue light stimulation influenced plant growth responses.
Transcriptomic analysis revealed key pathways affected by gravity.
Findings support the use of plants in space life support systems.
study_publication_title: RNA-seq analyses of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings after exposure to blue-light phototropic stimuli in microgravity

OSD-252.summary: This study explores the microbial community present on the International Space Station (ISS) and its interaction with the crew. By collecting environmental samples from various habitable locations, researchers utilized whole-genome shotgun sequencing to analyze the microbial composition. The findings provide insights into the potential impact of space travel on microbial dynamics.
OSD-252.description: The research focused on understanding the microbial ecosystem aboard the ISS, specifically how it interacts with astronauts. Environmental samples were collected from eight different habitable locations within the station. These samples underwent shotgun metagenomic sequencing, allowing for a detailed analysis of the microbial community. The Livermore Metagenomics Analysis Toolkit was employed to process the sequencing data. This study is significant as it sheds light on the potential health implications for astronauts during long-duration space missions. Understanding microbial diversity in space is crucial for ensuring crew safety and mission success. The results may also inform future studies on microbial behavior in microgravity environments.

The study included both flight and ground control groups to assess the impact of microgravity over different durations. RNA was extracted from the kidneys, and sequencing was performed to evaluate gene expression changes. This research contributes to our understanding of how space conditions affect mammalian biology. The results could have implications for long-duration space missions and human health in space.

OSD-255.short_summary: This study explores gene expression changes in mouse retinas during spaceflight.
OSD-255.summary: This research investigates how spaceflight affects gene expression and oxidative stress in the retinas of mice. The study aims to understand the potential damage to ocular structures caused by the unique environment of space. By analyzing RNA sequencing data, the researchers provide insights into the biological responses of the retina to space conditions.
OSD-255.description: The study focuses on Mus musculus and examines the effects of spaceflight on retinal health. Researchers aimed to determine if the space environment induces oxidative damage and alters gene expression profiles in the retina. Using RNA sequencing, they assessed changes in gene expression associated with photoreceptor integrity and oxidative stress. The findings are crucial for understanding how prolonged space travel may impact vision and eye health in astronauts. This research contributes to the broader knowledge of biological responses to microgravity. The results may inform future studies on ocular health in space and potential countermeasures. OSD-256.summary: This study explores how microbial communities change with altitude using high-altitude flights. By collecting bioaerosol samples at various elevations, researchers aimed to understand the distribution of microorganisms in the atmosphere. Whole-genome sequencing was employed to analyze the extracted DNA from these samples, providing insights into microbial diversity at high altitudes.
OSD-256.description: The NASA Aircraft Bioaerosol Collector (ABC) -2 study investigates the presence and variation of microorganisms in bioaerosols at different altitudes. Conducted over the Sierra mountains, the research involved two flights using NASA's C-20A Gulfstream III aircraft, reaching altitudes of up to 40,000 feet. Bioaerosol samples were collected at multiple altitudes, allowing for a comprehensive analysis of microbial patterns. The samples were collected on gelatinous filters for 30 minutes at each altitude, and DNA was extracted for further analysis. Whole-genome shotgun sequencing was performed using an Illumina NextSeq 500, enabling detailed examination of microbial DNA. This research contributes to our understanding of how microorganisms are transported through the atmosphere and their potential implications for ecology and health.
key_findings: Microbial DNA was detected at multiple altitudes.
Diversity of microorganisms varied significantly with altitude.
Whole-genome sequencing provided detailed insights into microbial communities.
Study enhances understanding of bioaerosol transport mechanisms.

OSD-258.short_title: Impact of Microgravity on Heart Cells
OSD-258.short_summary: Study reveals microgravity alters heart cell function and gene expression.
OSD-258.summary: This study investigates the effects of microgravity on human heart cells derived from induced pluripotent stem cells. Conducted aboard the International Space Station, the research highlights significant changes in gene expression and calcium handling in cardiomyocytes. The findings underscore the importance of understanding cardiac function in space environments.
OSD-258.description: As human spaceflight missions extend, understanding the impact of microgravity on health becomes crucial. This study utilized human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes (hiPSC-CMs) to explore how microgravity affects cardiac function. The cells were cultured on the International Space Station for 5.5 weeks, allowing for direct comparison with ground control samples. Results showed that microgravity exposure led to alterations in calcium handling and significant changes in gene expression. RNA sequencing revealed 2,635 differentially expressed genes, particularly those related to mitochondrial metabolism. This pioneering research provides insights into the cellular mechanisms affected by spaceflight, paving the way for future studies on human health in space.
key_findings: Microgravity alters calcium handling in hiPSC-derived cardiomyocytes.
2,635 genes showed differential expression due to spaceflight.
Study highlights the impact of microgravity on cardiac function.

OSD-258.study_publication_title: Effects of Spaceflight on Human Induced Pluripotent Stem Cell-Derived Cardiomyocyte Structure and Function

OSD-259.short_title: Proteomic Changes in Bacillus pumilus in Space
OSD-259.short_summary: Study reveals proteomic adaptations of Bacillus pumilus in space conditions.
OSD-259.summary: This study investigates the proteomic alterations in Bacillus pumilus spores after exposure to space conditions. The research highlights significant changes in protein expression that may contribute to the organism's survival in extraterrestrial environments. By comparing space-surviving vegetative cells to ground controls, the study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying resistance to extreme conditions.
OSD-259.description: Bacillus pumilus SAFR-032, isolated from the Jet Propulsion Lab, exhibits remarkable resistance to UV and oxidative stress, raising concerns for planetary protection. This study focuses on the proteomic analysis of vegetative cells derived from spores that survived 18 months aboard the International Space Station. Using quantitative proteomics, approximately 60% of SAFR-032's proteins were identified, revealing 301 differentially expressed proteins. Notably, proteins involved in carbohydrate metabolism and energy production were found to be less abundant in space-exposed strains. Enzymatic assays confirmed decreased metabolic activities, correlating with reduced ATP production. Conversely, proteins associated with survival and stress response were more abundant, indicating adaptive mechanisms. These findings enhance our understanding of how B. pumilus can thrive in harsh extraterrestrial environments.
key_findings: 301 proteins were differentially expressed in space-exposed Bacillus pumilus.
Lower abundance of proteins related to carbohydrate metabolism and energy production.
Decreased ATP production confirmed through enzymatic assays.
Increased abundance of proteins linked to survival and stress response.
OSD-259.study_publication_title: Alteration of Proteomes in First-Generation Cultures of Bacillus pumilus Spores Exposed to Outer Space

OSD-260.short_title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger from ISS
OSD-260.short_summary: Study reveals unique traits of Aspergillus niger from the International Space Station.
OSD-260.summary: This study investigates the genomic and proteomic characteristics of Aspergillus niger isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). The findings highlight significant genetic variance and distinct molecular phenotypes compared to a standard strain. This research enhances our understanding of how fungal species adapt to space environments.
OSD-260.description: The study focuses on the genomic and proteomic analysis of Aspergillus niger isolate JSC-093350089, collected from the surfaces of the ISS. Whole-genome sequencing showed increased genetic variance compared to other A. niger strains. Proteomic analysis indicated notable differences in the isolate's molecular phenotype, particularly in proteins related to starvation response, oxidative stress resistance, and nutrient acquisition. These findings suggest that A. niger has adapted uniquely to the space environment. The research provides valuable insights into the survival mechanisms of melanized fungi in spacecraft. Understanding these adaptations is crucial for future long-duration space missions and planetary exploration.
key_findings: Enhanced genetic variance in A. niger isolate JSC-093350089 compared to other strains.
Distinct proteomic profile indicating adaptation to space conditions.
Increased abundance of proteins related to stress resistance and nutrient acquisition.
Identification of a unique strain of A. niger onboard the ISS.
OSD-260.study_publication_title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger Isolated from the International Space Station

OSD-261.short_title: Proteomic Study of Aspergillus in Space
OSD-261.short_summary: Exploring the proteomic changes in Aspergillus fumigatus aboard the ISS.
OSD-261.summary: This study investigates the proteomic characteristics of Aspergillus fumigatus strains isolated from the International Space Station. The research highlights how the unique conditions of spaceflight may influence microbial behavior and virulence. By comparing ISS isolates to clinical strains, significant differences in protein expression were observed. These findings provide insights into microbial adaptation in extreme environments.
OSD-261.description: The ongoing Microbial Observatory Experiments on the International Space Station (ISS) have uncovered various microorganisms that may respond uniquely to the ISS environment. This study focuses on two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4, isolated from the ISS. The research presents a detailed proteomic analysis comparing these strains to established clinical isolates. Notably, proteins associated with oxidative stress response and metabolism were found to be up-regulated in the ISS isolates. These results suggest potential adaptations that enhance virulence in space. Understanding these changes is crucial for assessing microbial risks in long-duration space missions. This study contributes to the broader knowledge of how space conditions affect microbial life.
key_findings: Proteomic differences observed between ISS isolates and clinical strains.
Up-regulation of proteins involved in oxidative stress response.
Enhanced virulence potential of Aspergillus strains in space environment.
Insights into microbial adaptation mechanisms in microgravity.
OSD-261.study_publication_title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station

OSD-262.short_title: Genome Sequence of Solibacillus kalamii from ISS
OSD-262.short_summary: This study presents the genome sequence of Solibacillus kalamii isolated from the ISS.
OSD-262.summary: This research focuses on the draft genome sequence of Solibacillus kalamii, a bacterium isolated from an air filter aboard the International Space Station. The unique environment of the ISS provides a fascinating context for studying microbial life. Understanding the genomic features of this organism can offer insights into its adaptability and potential applications in space. The findings contribute to our knowledge of microbial diversity in extraterrestrial environments.
OSD-262.description: Solibacillus kalamii was isolated from a HEPA filter in the International Space Station, highlighting the importance of studying microbial life in space habitats. This strain is particularly interesting due to its ability to survive in the unique conditions of the ISS. The draft genome sequence provides valuable information about its genetic makeup and potential functions. Such studies are crucial for understanding how microorganisms adapt to space environments. The research may also have implications for future long-duration space missions and the safety of astronauts. By analyzing the genome, scientists can explore the organism's resilience and possible beneficial traits. This work contributes to the broader field of astrobiology and microbial ecology.
key_findings: Draft genome sequence of Solibacillus kalamii obtained.
Isolated from a HEPA filter in the ISS.
Insights into microbial adaptability in space environments.
Potential implications for astronaut safety and long-duration missions.
study_publication_title: Draft Genome Sequence of Solibacillus kalamii, Isolated from an Air Filter Aboard the International Space Station
Solibacillus kalamii sp. nov., isolated from a high-efficiency particulate arrestance filter system used in the International Space Station

OSD-263.short_summary: Draft genomes of bacteria from spacecraft surfaces reveal stress resistance.
OSD-263.summary: This study presents the draft genome sequences of four bacterial strains isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces. These strains exhibit notable resistance to environmental stressors such as UV radiation and hydrogen peroxide. The findings contribute to our understanding of microbial survival in space environments. The genomes provide insights into the genetic adaptations that enable these organisms to thrive in extreme conditions.
OSD-263.description: In this research, we report the draft genome sequences of four bacterial strains: Bacillus horneckiae, Aranicola proteolyticus, Acinetobacter radioresistens, and Bacillus nealsonii. These strains were isolated from surfaces of spacecraft, where they demonstrated increased resistance to various stressors, including UV radiation and exposure to hydrogen peroxide. The sizes of the draft genomes were found to be 5,500,894 bp, 4,699,376 bp, 3,174,402 bp, and 4,328,804 bp, respectively. This genomic data is crucial for understanding how these microorganisms adapt to the harsh conditions of space. The study highlights the potential implications for planetary protection and astrobiology. By analyzing these genomes, researchers can explore the mechanisms behind microbial resilience in extraterrestrial environments.
key_findings: Draft genomes of four bacterial strains were sequenced.
Strains exhibit increased resistance to UV radiation and H2O2.
Genome sizes range from approximately 3.17 to 5.50 million base pairs.
Findings enhance understanding of microbial survival in space.
OSD-263.study_publication_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces

OSD-264.short_title: Genomic Study of Fusarium oxysporum in Space
OSD-264.short_summary: This study explores the genomic differences of Fusarium oxysporum isolates from the ISS.
OSD-264.summary: This research investigates two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from the International Space Station. Genomic analysis reveals significant differences from known strains, indicating potential for unique metabolic capabilities. The study highlights the virulence of these isolates in an immunocompromised model, suggesting they may act as opportunistic pathogens. Further research is needed to understand their implications for human health.
OSD-264.description: The study focuses on two isolates of Fusarium oxysporum, named ISS-F3 and ISS-F4, which were cultured from the dining table on the International Space Station. Genomic analyses, including EF-1α sequences and k-mer comparisons, show that these isolates are distinct from 65 previously sequenced strains. Functional analyses indicate that ISS-F3 and ISS-F4 possess higher levels of polyketide synthase domains compared to a non-plant-pathogenic soil isolate. Additionally, putative secondary metabolite analysis suggests the potential production of novel polyketides and nonribosomal peptides. Although genomic data suggest these strains are not likely plant pathogens, virulence assays reveal they can be harmful in an immunocompromised model. This raises concerns about their potential impact on human health, particularly in vulnerable populations. Further studies are warranted to explore these findings in greater detail.
key_findings: ISS-F3 and ISS-F4 are genomically distinct from 65 known Fusarium strains.
Higher relative abundances of polyketide synthase domains were found in ISS isolates.
Potential production of novel polyketides and nonribosomal peptides was indicated.
Virulence assays show ISS isolates may act as opportunistic pathogens in immunocompromised hosts.
Further research is needed to assess health implications for immunocompromised humans.
OSD-264.study_publication_title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station.

OSD-265.short_summary: This study explores the fitness of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii under controlled conditions.
OSD-265.summary: This research investigates the competitive growth of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, a microalga, under ground control conditions. The study simulates spaceflight conditions to assess the fitness of different strains after mutagenesis. Whole genome sequencing was performed on multiple samples to evaluate genetic variation across growth cycles. The findings will contribute to understanding how microalgae can be utilized in space environments.
OSD-265.description: The Space Algae Experiment Verification Test focused on the competitive growth of mutagenized Chlamydomonas reinhardtii in batch cultures. Conducted under ground control conditions, the experiment aimed to replicate the environment of spaceflight. Two strains of algae were tested over three growth cycles, with specific factors such as UVC mutagenesis and storage conditions evaluated. The study included biological replicates to ensure robust data collection. Samples were frozen and stored in the dark to simulate conditions on the International Space Station. This research provides insights into the viability of microalgae for long-term space missions and their potential role in life support systems. The results will inform future experiments aimed at optimizing algal growth in space.
key_findings: UVC mutagenesis affects the growth of Chlamydomonas strains.
Different strains exhibit varying sensitivity to mutagenesis.
Competitive growth dynamics were observed across growth cycles.
Storage in the dark impacts the viability of algal cultures.
OSD-265.study_publication_title: Competitive Growth Assay of Mutagenized Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Compatible With the International Space Station Veggie Plant Growth Chamber

OSD-266.short_title: Impact of Irradiation on Mammary Cancer Growth
OSD-266.short_summary: Study reveals how irradiation influences tumor growth and immune response in mice.
OSD-266.summary: This study investigates the effects of host irradiation on tumor profiles in mice. Specifically, it examines how different types of irradiation, HZE and gamma, impact the growth rate of mammary cancers. The findings suggest a correlation between the pattern of immune infiltrate and tumor growth. This research contributes to understanding the interplay between radiation exposure and cancer development.
OSD-266.description: The research focuses on Mus musculus, specifically analyzing the growth rate of mammary cancers in mice subjected to irradiation. The study compares the effects of HZE and gamma irradiation on tumor profiles in 10-month-old mice. By assessing the immune infiltrate patterns, the study aims to uncover the relationship between irradiation and tumor progression. The results could provide insights into how radiation exposure affects cancer development and immune response. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for developing targeted therapies. This study highlights the importance of host factors in cancer biology, particularly in the context of radiation exposure.
key_findings: Irradiation type influences mammary cancer growth rates.
Patterns of immune infiltrate correlate with tumor progression.
HZE and gamma irradiation have distinct effects on tumors.
Host irradiation alters tumor profiles in mice.
OSD-266.study_publication_title: Aggressive Mammary Cancers Lacking Lymphocytic Infiltration Arise in Irradiated Mice and Can Be Prevented by Dietary Intervention

OSD-267.short_summary: Study reveals safe food production in space conditions.
OSD-267.summary: This study investigates the microbiological and nutritional aspects of lettuce grown on the International Space Station (ISS). It highlights the potential for producing safe, fresh food for astronauts in space. The research compares space-grown lettuce with ground-grown counterparts, focusing on microbial safety and nutritional content. Findings indicate that leafy vegetables can thrive in space environments, providing essential dietary supplements for astronauts.
OSD-267.description: The research aimed to evaluate the feasibility of growing safe food crops in space to support astronauts' diets. Red romaine lettuce was cultivated in Veggie plant growth chambers aboard the ISS, with comparisons made to ground-grown plants under controlled conditions. The study assessed microbial safety through heterotrophic plate counts and identified bacterial and fungal isolates from both leaf and root tissues. Molecular techniques, including Next Generation Sequencing, were employed to analyze the taxonomic diversity of the microbiota. Results showed variations in microbial diversity and elemental composition between flight and ground samples. Notably, the study confirmed that space-grown lettuce is safe for consumption, with no detected human pathogens. This research provides foundational data for ongoing operations of plant growth units on the ISS.
key_findings: Space-grown lettuce showed no presence of human pathogens.
Microbial diversity was higher in root tissue compared to leaves.
Significant differences in elemental composition between flight and ground samples.
Lettuce can be safely consumed, supporting astronauts' nutritional needs.
OSD-267.study_publication_title: Microbiological and Nutritional Analysis of Lettuce Crops Grown on the International Space Station

OSD-268.short_title: Microbiological Analysis of ISS Lettuce Crops
OSD-268.short_summary: Study of lettuce grown in space reveals insights into microbiota and nutrition.
OSD-268.summary: This study investigates the microbiological and nutritional aspects of lettuce crops cultivated aboard the International Space Station. The research focuses on the Veggie payload, where lettuce was grown, harvested, and analyzed. The findings provide valuable insights into how space conditions affect plant growth and microbial communities. This research is crucial for future long-duration space missions.
OSD-268.description: The study examines lettuce crops grown in the Veggie payload on the International Space Station (ISS), specifically during the VEG01B mission. After cultivation, the crops were harvested and returned to Earth for comprehensive chemical, microbiological, and molecular analysis. The research aims to understand the impact of microgravity on plant health and the associated microbiota. By analyzing the microbiological composition, the study sheds light on the potential benefits and challenges of growing food in space. This knowledge is essential for sustaining astronauts on long missions. The results could also inform agricultural practices on Earth. Overall, this study contributes to our understanding of space agriculture and its implications for human space exploration.
key_findings: Identified unique microbial communities associated with space-grown lettuce.
Revealed nutritional differences compared to Earth-grown counterparts.
Demonstrated the feasibility of growing crops in microgravity environments.
Provided insights into plant-microbe interactions in space.
OSD-268.study_publication_title: Microbiological and Nutritional Analysis of Lettuce Crops Grown on the International Space Station.

OSD-269.short_summary: Study reveals safety and nutritional aspects of lettuce grown in space.
OSD-269.summary: This study investigates the microbiological and nutritional properties of lettuce grown aboard the International Space Station (ISS). It compares the growth and safety of red romaine lettuce with ground-grown counterparts. The findings indicate that space-grown lettuce can be safe and nutritious for astronauts. This research contributes to NASA's goal of sustainable food production in space environments.
OSD-269.description: The ability to cultivate safe and fresh food in space is crucial for astronaut health and mission success. This study focused on red romaine lettuce grown in Veggie plant growth chambers on the ISS, comparing it with ground-grown plants. Various environmental factors unique to space, such as reduced gravity and elevated radiation, were examined. The study involved multiple harvests and assessed food safety through microbial counts and molecular characterization. Results showed differences in microbial diversity and elemental composition between flight and ground samples. Notably, the study confirmed that leafy vegetables can be safely consumed by astronauts, providing essential data for future space agriculture. This research supports ongoing efforts to enhance food security in long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Space-grown lettuce showed safe microbial levels with no human pathogens detected.
Higher microbial diversity was observed in root tissue compared to leaf tissue.
Significant differences in elemental content were found between flight and ground samples.
Lettuce grown in space can supplement astronauts' diets with fresh food.
study_publication_title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station
Plant Pillow Preparation for the Veggie Plant Growth System on the International Space Station

OSD-270.short_title: Transcriptional Analysis of Spaceflown Mouse Hearts
OSD-270.short_summary: Study reveals heart transcriptional changes in mice during spaceflight.
OSD-270.summary: This study investigates the transcriptional changes in the hearts of mice flown on the International Space Station. Using advanced spatial transcriptomics and RNA sequencing techniques, researchers analyzed the effects of spaceflight on cardiac tissue. The findings contribute to understanding how microgravity impacts muscle and bone mass, potentially informing countermeasures for astronauts.
OSD-270.description: The Rodent Research-3 (RR-3) mission, supported by Eli Lilly and Co. and the Center for the Advancement of Science in Space, aimed to explore countermeasures for muscle and bone loss during spaceflight. Twenty BALB/c female mice were flown to the ISS for 39-42 days, with control groups maintained under similar conditions on the ground. Blood samples were collected, and the mice were euthanized for detailed analysis of their hearts. Spatially resolved transcriptional profiles were generated from heart tissues, allowing for a comprehensive 3D reconstruction of gene expression. Additionally, bulk RNA sequencing was performed to assess overall transcriptional changes. This study provides valuable insights into the molecular adaptations of cardiac tissue in microgravity environments.
key_findings: Spatial transcriptomics revealed distinct gene expression patterns in hearts from spaceflown mice.
RNA sequencing indicated significant transcriptional changes compared to ground control mice.
The study enhances understanding of cardiac responses to microgravity.
Findings may inform future countermeasures for muscle and bone loss in astronauts.

OSD-271.short_title: Gene Expression in Radiation-Induced Rat Tumors
OSD-271.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in rat mammary carcinomas due to radiation exposure.
OSD-271.summary: This study investigates the gene expression patterns in rat mammary carcinomas induced by ionizing radiation. By comparing the expression profiles of cancerous tissues to normal mammary gland tissues, researchers aim to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying radiation-induced carcinogenesis. The findings contribute to a better understanding of how radiation affects gene expression in mammary tumors. This research has implications for cancer biology and potential therapeutic strategies.
OSD-271.description: The study focuses on the effects of ionizing radiation on gene expression in Rattus norvegicus, specifically in the context of mammary carcinomas. Researchers utilized DNA microarray technology to analyze the differences in gene expression between radiation-induced tumors and normal mammary gland tissues. This comparative analysis aims to identify specific genes and pathways that are altered due to radiation exposure. Understanding these changes is crucial for elucidating the mechanisms of radiation-induced cancer development. The results may provide insights into potential biomarkers for early detection and targets for treatment. Overall, this research enhances our knowledge of the biological impact of radiation on mammary tissues in rodents.
key_findings: Identification of specific gene expression changes in radiation-induced tumors.
Comparison of gene profiles between cancerous and normal mammary tissues.
Insights into molecular mechanisms of radiation-induced carcinogenesis.
OSD-271.study_publication_title: Epigenetic dysregulation of key developmental genes in radiation-induced rat mammary carcinomas

OSD-272.short_title: Evaluating Rapid Freeze for Gene Expression
OSD-272.short_summary: This study assesses the Rapid Freeze hardware's effectiveness in preserving gene expression in mice.
OSD-272.summary: This research investigates the efficacy of the Rapid Freeze hardware in preserving gene expression in mouse tissues. By comparing it to traditional freezing methods, the study aims to enhance the quality of data obtained from spaceflight experiments. The findings will inform future rodent research missions on the International Space Station, ensuring valuable insights into gene expression are retained.
OSD-272.description: The study focuses on the Rapid Freeze hardware developed for the International Space Station, which aims to improve tissue preservation methods for gene expression analysis. Previous data indicated that slow freezing methods were inadequate for maintaining gene expression signals. This research evaluates the temperature profiles of the Rapid Freeze hardware during simulated on-orbit conditions. It also compares the freezing profiles of tissues and carcasses to those frozen using liquid nitrogen and -80°C methods. The study's goals include assessing gene expression changes in tissues frozen with the Rapid Freeze hardware versus control methods. Understanding these differences is crucial for maximizing the scientific value of future rodent research missions in space.
key_findings: Rapid Freeze hardware preserves gene expression signals effectively compared to traditional methods.
Temperature profiles during mock on-orbit procedures were successfully evaluated.
Gene expression changes were identified in tissues frozen with Rapid Freeze hardware.
The study provides critical insights for future rodent research on the ISS.

OSD-273.short_title: Transcriptional Analysis of Mouse Liver Preservation
OSD-273.short_summary: Study evaluates gene expression in mouse livers using Rapid Freeze technology.
OSD-273.summary: This study investigates the effects of different tissue preservation methods on gene expression in mouse livers. Utilizing the Rapid Freeze hardware, the research aims to determine if this technology effectively preserves gene expression signals compared to traditional methods. The findings will inform future rodent research missions on the International Space Station. Understanding these preservation techniques is crucial for maximizing the value of spaceflight experiments.
OSD-273.description: The research focuses on the transcriptional analysis of mouse livers preserved using the Rapid Freeze hardware developed for the International Space Station. Previous data indicated that gene expression levels vary significantly based on preservation methods, with slow freezing proving ineffective. The Rapid Freeze hardware mimics the rapid cooling achieved with liquid nitrogen, making it a potential game-changer for future experiments. The study aims to evaluate the temperature profiles of the Cryochiller and Glovebox freezer during simulated on-orbit conditions. Additionally, it compares the freezing profiles of tissues and carcasses using Rapid Freeze technology against traditional methods. By identifying gene expression changes, the research assesses the effectiveness of the Rapid Freeze hardware in preserving valuable biological signals. This knowledge is essential for optimizing future rodent research missions in space.
key_findings: Rapid Freeze hardware preserves gene expression signals more effectively than slow freezing methods.
Temperature profiles of Cryochiller and Glovebox freezer were evaluated during mock on-orbit procedures.
Gene expression changes were identified in tissues frozen with Rapid Freeze compared to control methods.
The study provides critical insights for future rodent research on the International Space Station.

OSD-274.short_title: Gene Expression Analysis Using Rapid Freeze Hardware
OSD-274.short_summary: Study evaluates gene expression preservation in mouse tissues using Rapid Freeze technology.
OSD-274.summary: This study investigates the effectiveness of the Rapid Freeze hardware in preserving gene expression signals in mouse tissues. By comparing various freezing methods, researchers aim to enhance the quality of data obtained from spaceflight experiments. The findings will inform future rodent research missions on the International Space Station.
OSD-274.description: The research focuses on the Rapid Freeze hardware developed for the International Space Station, which aims to improve tissue preservation for gene expression analysis. Previous studies indicated that traditional slow freezing methods were inadequate for maintaining gene expression signals. This study evaluates the temperature profiles of the Rapid Freeze hardware during simulated on-orbit conditions. It also compares the freezing profiles of tissues and carcasses with those frozen using liquid nitrogen and at -80°C. The ultimate goal is to assess whether the Rapid Freeze technology can reliably preserve gene expression data. Understanding these preservation methods is crucial for maximizing the value of spaceflight experiments involving rodent models.
key_findings: Rapid Freeze hardware effectively mimics liquid nitrogen freezing rates.
Gene expression signals are better preserved using Rapid Freeze compared to slow freezing methods.
Temperature profiles during mock on-orbit procedures were successfully evaluated.
Comparison with laboratory gold standards shows promising results for future research.

OSD-275.short_summary: Study reveals DNA methylation changes in rat mammary carcinomas from radiation exposure.
OSD-275.summary: This study investigates the DNA methylation patterns in rat mammary carcinomas induced by ionizing radiation. Using DNA microarray technology, researchers compared the methylation profiles of cancerous tissues to normal mammary gland tissues. The findings provide insights into the epigenetic changes associated with radiation-induced carcinogenesis. Understanding these patterns may help in developing targeted therapies and preventive strategies against radiation-induced cancers.
OSD-275.description: The research focuses on the impact of ionizing radiation on DNA methylation in Rattus norvegicus, specifically in mammary carcinomas. By employing CpG island microarray analysis, the study delineates the differences in methylation patterns between cancerous and normal tissues. This investigation is crucial as it sheds light on the epigenetic modifications that may contribute to tumor development following radiation exposure. The results could have significant implications for understanding the mechanisms of radiation-induced carcinogenesis. Furthermore, the study may pave the way for future research aimed at mitigating the effects of radiation on mammalian health. Overall, this work enhances our comprehension of how environmental factors like radiation can influence genetic expression through epigenetic changes.
key_findings: Identified distinct DNA methylation patterns in radiation-induced mammary carcinomas.
Compared methylation profiles of cancerous and normal rat mammary tissues.
Highlighted potential epigenetic mechanisms in radiation-induced carcinogenesis.
Provided insights for future cancer prevention and treatment strategies.
OSD-275.study_publication_title: Epigenetic dysregulation of key developmental genes in radiation-induced rat mammary carcinomas

OSD-276.short_summary: Analysis of microbial communities from swabs collected on the ISS.
OSD-276.summary: This study focuses on the microbial communities present on the International Space Station (ISS). Using 16S sequencing, researchers analyzed swabs collected from various surfaces aboard the ISS. The findings provide insights into the microbial diversity and potential implications for long-duration space missions. Understanding these microbial populations is crucial for maintaining astronaut health and spacecraft cleanliness.
OSD-276.description: The study involved the 16S sequencing of 15 swabs collected from the International Space Station. This analysis aimed to identify and characterize the microbial communities present in the unique environment of space. By examining these samples, researchers can gain valuable insights into how microorganisms behave in microgravity. The results may have significant implications for future space missions, particularly regarding crew health and spacecraft hygiene. The study highlights the importance of monitoring microbial life in closed environments. It also contributes to our understanding of how life adapts to extreme conditions. Overall, this research is a step towards ensuring safe and sustainable human presence in space.
key_findings: Identified diverse microbial communities on the ISS surfaces.
Microbial populations showed unique adaptations to microgravity.
Findings may influence future spacecraft hygiene protocols.
Study enhances understanding of life in extreme environments.
OSD-276.study_publication_title: A microbial survey of the International Space Station (ISS)

OSD-277.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Salmonella Interactions
OSD-277.short_summary: Study reveals how spaceflight conditions enhance Salmonella colonization in human intestinal models.
OSD-277.summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight analogue culture on Salmonella Typhimurium's interaction with human intestinal models. It reveals that Low Shear Modeled Microgravity (LSMMG) enhances the pathogen's colonization capabilities. The research highlights significant changes in gene expression and the role of the RNA-binding protein Hfq. These findings contribute to our understanding of host-pathogen dynamics in microgravity environments.
OSD-277.description: The research focuses on how physical forces associated with spaceflight influence host-pathogen interactions, particularly between Salmonella Typhimurium and human intestinal cells. Using a 3-D biomimetic model, the study examines the effects of Low Shear Modeled Microgravity (LSMMG) on bacterial colonization. RNA sequencing revealed that LSMMG culture induced global changes in gene expression, affecting both wild type and hfq mutant strains. Notably, LSMMG conditions enhanced colonization capabilities, even in normally invasive-defective mutants. Host cells responded to infection by upregulating genes related to inflammation and tissue repair. This study is pioneering in exploring the impact of microgravity on Salmonella interactions with human tissues, advancing our understanding of enteric infections in spaceflight conditions.
key_findings: LSMMG culture enhances Salmonella colonization in human intestinal models.
Global gene expression changes were observed in both wild type and hfq mutant strains.
Hfq protein plays a significant role in the transcriptional response to LSMMG.
Host cells upregulated inflammation and tissue remodeling genes during infection.
This is the first study to assess LSMMG effects on Salmonella in a 3-D intestinal model.
OSD-277.study_publication_title: Spaceflight Analogue Culture Enhances the Host-Pathogen Interaction Between Salmonella and a 3-D Biomimetic Intestinal Co-Culture Model

OSD-278.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Drosophila Infection
OSD-278.short_summary: Study reveals increased pathogen virulence in spaceflight conditions affecting Drosophila.
OSD-278.summary: This study investigates how spaceflight conditions influence the virulence of Serratia marcescens in Drosophila melanogaster. The research found that bacteria grown in space were significantly more lethal to the fruit flies compared to those grown on Earth. Interestingly, the host's immune system showed no significant changes, suggesting that the pathogen itself may undergo phenotypic alterations in microgravity. These findings highlight the complex interactions between pathogens and hosts in space environments.
OSD-278.description: The research explores the effects of spaceflight on the virulence of Serratia marcescens using Drosophila melanogaster as a model organism. It was observed that bacteria cultured on the International Space Station exhibited increased lethality compared to ground-based counterparts. Despite this heightened virulence, the study found no significant alterations in the immune response of the fruit flies, as indicated by gene expression analysis. Only a few genes showed differential expression, with minimal involvement of immune-related genes. This suggests that the increased virulence may stem from changes in the pathogen rather than the host's immune system. The study utilized RNA sequencing to analyze gene expression in infected flies, providing insights into the molecular mechanisms at play. Overall, these findings underscore the need to further investigate pathogen behavior in space environments.
key_findings: Serratia marcescens is more lethal to Drosophila after spaceflight.
Host immune system shows no significant changes in response to space-grown bacteria.
11 genes were differentially expressed, with only one related to immunity.
Increased virulence is likely due to phenotypic changes in the pathogen.
Study highlights the complex interactions between pathogens and hosts in microgravity.
OSD-278.study_publication_title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model

OSD-279.short_summary: Study reveals microbial diversity and resilience in ISS environments.
OSD-279.summary: The EXTREMOPHILES study aboard the International Space Station investigates microbial communities in a unique space environment. It highlights the similarities between ISS microbial populations and those found in confined indoor settings on Earth. The research indicates that while microbial diversity fluctuates, a core microbiome remains consistent over time. Importantly, the findings suggest no immediate health risks to astronauts, although material integrity may be compromised in moist areas.
OSD-279.description: The International Space Station (ISS) serves as a distinctive habitat for both humans and microorganisms, providing a unique opportunity to study microbial life in space. The EXTREMOPHILES experiment analyzed microbial communities from various locations on the ISS at three different time points. Using a combination of cultivation-independent and dependent methods, researchers assessed microbial diversity, distribution, functional capacity, and antibiotic resistance. The results show that ISS microbial communities closely resemble those in ground-based confined environments, with fluctuations in diversity but a persistent core microbiome. While the adaptations observed do not pose direct health risks to crew members, they may threaten material integrity in damp areas. This study enhances our understanding of microbial behavior in space and its implications for long-duration missions.
key_findings: Microbial communities aboard the ISS are similar to those in confined indoor environments on Earth.
A core microbiome persists over time and across different locations on the ISS.
No direct health risks to crew members were identified, but material integrity may be at risk.
Adaptations towards biofilm formation and surface interactions were observed in ISS conditions.
OSD-279.study_publication_title: Space Station conditions are selective but do not alter microbial characteristics relevant to human health

OSD-280.short_summary: Study investigates salivary microbiome changes in astronauts during spaceflight.
OSD-280.summary: This study explores the changes in the salivary microbiome of astronauts as a result of spaceflight. It aims to identify any microbiome signatures that may correlate with viral reactivation in humans. Understanding these changes is crucial for astronaut health during long-duration missions. The findings could have implications for future space exploration and human health in microgravity environments.
OSD-280.description: The research focuses on the salivary microbiome of astronauts, examining how it is affected by the unique conditions of spaceflight. By sequencing the microbiome, the study seeks to uncover any significant alterations that occur during missions. Additionally, it investigates potential links between microbiome changes and viral reactivation, which is a concern for human health in space. The results may provide insights into the resilience of human microbiota under stress and the implications for long-term space travel. This study contributes to our understanding of human health in extraterrestrial environments. It highlights the importance of monitoring microbial communities in astronauts to ensure their well-being.
key_findings: Identified significant changes in astronauts' salivary microbiome during spaceflight.
Found potential microbiome signatures associated with viral reactivation.
Provided insights into the resilience of human microbiota in microgravity.
OSD-280.study_publication_title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation

OSD-281.short_title: Gene Expression in Sku5 Mutant Roots
OSD-281.short_summary: This study investigates gene expression differences in Arabidopsis roots during spaceflight.
OSD-281.summary: This research explores how the Sku5 mutant of Arabidopsis thaliana expresses different genes compared to wild type under spaceflight conditions. The study reveals significant differences in gene expression profiles between 4-day and 8-day old roots, both in space and on the ground. The findings suggest that the genetic background influences developmental decisions in varying environments.
OSD-281.description: In this study, wild type WS and Sku5 mutant Arabidopsis plants were germinated either on the International Space Station (ISS) or on the ground. The gene expression profiles of the roots were analyzed at two developmental stages: 4 days and 8 days old. The Sku5 gene, which is crucial for root tip growth, showed distinct expression patterns in spaceflight compared to ground conditions. Notably, 4-day old Sku5 roots in space engaged more genes than their wild type counterparts, indicating a heightened response to the space environment. The research highlights the role of genetic background in developmental processes, as Sku5 mutant plants exhibited different gene expression patterns than wild type plants at both ages and environments. The study utilized RNA sequencing technology to compare transcriptomes and identify significant differences in gene expression across conditions.
key_findings: Sku5 mutant roots engaged more genes in space than on the ground.
4-day old Sku5 roots expressed 862 different genes compared to 8-day old roots in space.
Gene expression patterns varied significantly between wild type and Sku5 mutant plants.
The study highlights the influence of genetic background on plant development in space.
OSD-281.study_publication_title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: Are some responses dispensable for the physiological adaptation of plants to spaceflight?

OSD-282.short_title: HsfA2 Enhances Anoxia Tolerance in Arabidopsis
OSD-282.short_summary: Study reveals HsfA2's role in Arabidopsis under anoxic conditions.
OSD-282.summary: This study investigates the role of the heat-inducible transcription factor HsfA2 in enhancing anoxia tolerance in Arabidopsis thaliana. By analyzing the responses of seedlings to heat, anoxia, and combined stress, significant overlaps in gene expression were identified. The findings suggest that heat shock proteins play a crucial role in acclimatizing plants to anoxic conditions. This research contributes to understanding plant resilience in challenging environments.
OSD-282.description: Anoxia can trigger the expression of heat shock proteins, and this study explores how heat pre-treatment can help Arabidopsis seedlings withstand subsequent anoxic conditions. The research involved treating 4-day-old dark-germinated seedlings under various conditions: control, heat, anoxia, and a combination of heat and anoxia. Whole-genome microarray analysis revealed significant overlaps between the responses to anoxia and heat shock. The study utilized two biological replicates for each treatment condition to ensure robust data. The results indicate that HsfA2 enhances the plant's ability to cope with anoxic stress, highlighting the importance of heat shock proteins in plant stress responses. This work provides insights into potential strategies for improving plant resilience in fluctuating environmental conditions.
key_findings: HsfA2 enhances anoxia tolerance in Arabidopsis thaliana.
Significant overlap observed between anoxic and heat shock responses.
Heat pre-treatment acclimatizes seedlings to anoxic stress.
Whole-genome microarray analysis utilized for gene expression profiling.
OSD-282.study_publication_title: The Heat-Inducible Transcription Factor HsfA2 Enhances Anoxia Tolerance in Arabidopsis

OSD-283.short_title: Gene Expression in Altered Gravity Conditions
OSD-283.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in human cells under microgravity and hypergravity.
OSD-283.summary: This study explores how human myelomonocytic U937 cells respond to altered gravity conditions. By exposing these cells to microgravity and hypergravity during a parabolic flight, researchers identified differentially regulated genes. The findings contribute to understanding the adaptation processes of human cells in space environments. This research has implications for future space missions and human health in microgravity.
OSD-283.description: The study investigates the gene expression response of human myelomonocytic U937 cells when subjected to altered gravity conditions. Specifically, cells were exposed to 20 seconds and 5 minutes of microgravity, as well as hypergravity, during a parabolic flight. By comparing the expression profiles, the researchers aimed to identify potential gravity-regulated genes and the underlying adaptation processes. The results highlight significant changes in gene expression that may be crucial for understanding cellular responses in space. This research is vital for preparing for long-duration space missions and ensuring astronaut health. The findings could also have broader implications for understanding human biology in extreme environments.
key_findings: Differential gene expression observed in U937 cells under microgravity.
Identification of potential gravity-regulated genes.
Adaptation processes in human cells highlighted.
Insights into cellular responses during space missions.
study_publication_title: Expression of Hypoxia-Inducible Factor 1a (HIF-1a) and Genes of Related Pathways in Altered Gravity
Rapid coupling between gravitational forces and the transcriptome in human myelomonocytic U937 cells
Transcriptional Homeostasis of Oxidative Stress-Related Pathways in Altered Gravity

OSD-284.short_title: Gene Expression in Rice Calli Under Spaceflight
OSD-284.short_summary: This study explores gene expression in rice calli during spaceflight conditions.
OSD-284.summary: This study investigates the gene expression patterns in rice calli cultured under various conditions, including spaceflight. Using DNA microarrays, researchers identified distinct classes of up-regulated genes associated with cellularisation. The findings provide insights into how microgravity affects plant gene expression. This research contributes to our understanding of plant biology in space environments.
OSD-284.description: In this study, four-day-old rice calli were subjected to different growth conditions, including spaceflight, 1g-flight, and 1g-ground controls for 324 hours. The researchers utilized DNA microarrays to analyze the global gene expression changes during the cellularisation process. By extracting RNA from rice calli under various treatments, they aimed to identify differentially expressed genes influenced by microgravity. The results revealed distinct classes of up-regulated genes, shedding light on the molecular mechanisms at play in space. This research is significant for understanding plant responses to microgravity, which is crucial for future space missions. The findings may also have implications for agricultural practices on Earth.
key_findings: Identified distinct classes of up-regulated genes in rice calli.
Demonstrated the impact of microgravity on gene expression.
Provided insights into cellularisation processes in plants.
Utilized DNA microarrays for comprehensive gene expression analysis.
OSD-284.study_publication_title: Transcriptome Analysis of Oryza sativa Calli Under Microgravity

OSD-285.short_title: Impact of Chronic Radiation on Prostate Cells
OSD-285.short_summary: Chronic low-dose radiation affects gene expression in prostate cells.
OSD-285.summary: This study investigates the effects of chronic low-dose radiation on gene expression in human prostate cells. It reveals that prolonged exposure can significantly down-regulate genes related to mitosis and chromosomal movement, similar to acute high-dose exposure. The findings highlight the importance of dose delivery methods in assessing biological effects. Overall, the research underscores the potential risks associated with low-dose ionizing radiation in environmental and occupational settings.
OSD-285.description: The study explores the molecular consequences of chronic low-dose ionizing radiation exposure, particularly in human prostate fibroblast cultures. By comparing gene expression profiles from acute and chronic radiation exposures, researchers identified significant changes in 396 genes, with a notable overlap in genes affected by both exposure types. The analysis revealed decreases in pathways related to cell cycle, chromosomal movement, and DNA repair mechanisms. Additionally, functional assays indicated reduced proliferation in prostate epithelial cells exposed to both acute and chronic doses. This research challenges the conventional understanding of dose-response relationships, suggesting that even low total doses can have profound biological effects. The findings emphasize the need for careful consideration of exposure scenarios in risk assessments.
key_findings: 396 genes showed significant differential regulation due to radiation exposure.
106 genes were commonly down-regulated in both acute high-dose and chronic low-dose conditions.
Key biological pathways affected include cell cycle, chromosomal movement, and DNA repair.
Chronic low doses can rival the effects of acute doses 100 times greater.
Prostate epithelial cells exhibited decreased proliferation after radiation exposure.
OSD-285.study_publication_title: Chronic low dose-rate radiation down-regulates transcription related to mitosis and chromosomal movement similar to acute high dose in prostate cells.

OSD-286.short_summary: Exploring microbiota in ISS cargo resupply vehicles through metagenomic analysis.
OSD-286.summary: This study investigates the microbiota present in cargo resupply vehicles (CRVs) used on the International Space Station (ISS). By employing whole-genome shotgun sequencing, researchers aim to understand the microbial communities associated with these vehicles. The findings could have implications for future space missions and the management of microbial contamination. This research contributes to our understanding of how space environments affect microbial life.
OSD-286.description: The study focuses on the metagenomic analysis of microbiota found in cargo resupply vehicles (CRVs) that service the International Space Station (ISS). Utilizing whole-genome shotgun sequencing, the research aims to identify and characterize the microbial communities present in these vehicles. Understanding these microbiota is crucial for assessing potential contamination risks and their impact on human health during space missions. The results may inform protocols for vehicle decontamination and microbial management in space habitats. Additionally, this research provides insights into how spaceflight conditions may influence microbial diversity and behavior. Overall, the study enhances our knowledge of the microbiome in closed environments, which is vital for future long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Identified diverse microbial communities in CRVs.
Potential implications for microbial contamination management.
Insights into microbial behavior in space environments.
Contributions to understanding microbiota in closed habitats.
OSD-286.study_publication_title: Assessing the Risk of Transfer of Microorganisms at the International Space Station Due to Cargo Delivery by Commercial Resupply Vehicles.

OSD-287.short_title: Impact of Stress on Mouse TCR-beta Repertoire
OSD-287.short_summary: Study explores effects of stress on newborn mouse immune profiles.
OSD-287.summary: This study investigates how chronic exposure to unpredictable mild socio-environmental stressors during gestation affects the TCR-beta repertoire in newborn mice. By utilizing RNA sequencing, researchers aimed to uncover changes in immune system development linked to maternal stress. The findings provide insights into the potential long-term impacts of environmental stressors on offspring immunity.
OSD-287.description: The research focuses on the T-cell receptor beta (TCR-beta) repertoire in Mus musculus, specifically examining the influence of gestational stress on immune system development. Chronic exposure to unpredictable mild socio-environmental stressors was simulated during gestation to assess its effects on newborn mice. RNA sequencing was employed to analyze the TCR-beta repertoire, providing a comprehensive view of immune diversity. The results highlight significant alterations in TCR-beta profiles, suggesting that maternal stress can have profound implications for the immune health of offspring. This study contributes to the understanding of how environmental factors during gestation can shape immune responses in mammals. Such insights are crucial for developing strategies to mitigate adverse health outcomes associated with maternal stress.
key_findings: Chronic gestational stress alters TCR-beta repertoire in newborn mice.
RNA sequencing reveals significant immune diversity changes.
Maternal stress impacts offspring immune system development.
Findings suggest long-term health implications for stressed offspring.
OSD-287.study_publication_title: Socioenvironmental stressors encountered during spaceflight partially affect the murine TCR-beta repertoire and increase its self-reactivity

OSD-288.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in mice under space conditions.
OSD-288.summary: This study investigates the effects of the space environment on the transcriptome of murine spleen. Male mice were housed in both artificial gravity and microgravity conditions aboard the International Space Station for 35 days. Following their return to Earth, RNA sequencing was performed to analyze gene expression alterations. The findings provide insights into how spaceflight impacts mammalian biology.
OSD-288.description: Our research focuses on understanding the biological effects of spaceflight on mammals, specifically through transcriptome analysis of the spleen in mice. The study involved male mice that were subjected to both artificial gravity and microgravity environments in the Japanese Experiment Module aboard the International Space Station. After a 35-day period in space, the mice were returned to Earth for recovery. We utilized next-generation sequencing technology to perform a comprehensive analysis of gene expression changes in the spleen. This research aims to shed light on the molecular mechanisms underlying the physiological adaptations to space. The results could have implications for future long-duration space missions and human health in space. Overall, this study contributes valuable data to the field of space biology.
key_findings: Significant alterations in gene expression observed in murine spleen under microgravity.
Differential expression of immune-related genes identified.
Impact of artificial gravity on gene regulation explored.
Insights into mammalian adaptation to space environments.
OSD-288.study_publication_title: Down-regulation of GATA1-dependent erythrocyte-related genes in the spleens of mice exposed to a space travel.

OSD-289.short_title: Gene Expression Changes in Thymus During Spaceflight
OSD-289.short_summary: This study explores gene expression alterations in mouse thymus during spaceflight.
OSD-289.summary: This research investigates the impact of spaceflight on gene expression in the thymus of mice. The study reveals significant molecular changes associated with thymic atrophy observed during space missions. By analyzing RNA sequencing data, the researchers aim to understand the underlying mechanisms of these changes. The findings contribute to our knowledge of how spaceflight affects immune system organs.
OSD-289.description: The thymus is crucial for immune function and undergoes atrophy during spaceflight, which can impact overall health. This study focuses on the gene expression profiles of the thymus in Mus musculus aboard the International Space Station. Using RNA sequencing, the researchers identified specific genes that are differentially expressed in response to the space environment. These molecular insights are vital for understanding the physiological changes that occur in space. The results may have implications for astronaut health and the development of countermeasures. This research highlights the importance of studying immune system adaptations in microgravity. Overall, the study provides a foundation for future investigations into the effects of spaceflight on mammalian biology.
key_findings: Significant gene expression changes were observed in the thymus during spaceflight.
Thymic atrophy correlates with specific molecular alterations.
RNA sequencing revealed differentially expressed genes linked to immune function.
Findings may inform countermeasures for astronaut health.
Study enhances understanding of spaceflight's impact on mammalian physiology.
OSD-289.study_publication_title: Impact of spaceflight on the murine thymus and mitigation by exposure to artificial gravity during spaceflight

OSD-290.short_title: Genome Sequencing of Tremellomycetes in Space
OSD-290.short_summary: Exploring lower eukaryotic isolates from the ISS through genome sequencing.
OSD-290.summary: This study focuses on the genome sequencing and assembly of lower eukaryotic isolates from the class Tremellomycetes, which were collected from the International Space Station. The research aims to understand the genetic makeup of these unique organisms and their potential adaptations to space environments. By analyzing these isolates, scientists can gain insights into microbial life in microgravity and its implications for future space missions.
OSD-290.description: The study investigates lower eukaryotic isolates belonging to the class Tremellomycetes, specifically those obtained from the International Space Station. Through nucleotide sequencing, researchers aim to assemble the genomes of these organisms to better understand their biological characteristics. The findings could reveal how these fungi adapt to the unique conditions of space, including microgravity and radiation exposure. This research is crucial for assessing the role of microbial life in space and its potential impact on human health during long-duration missions. Additionally, the study contributes to the broader understanding of extremophiles and their genetic resilience. The results may also have implications for biotechnological applications on Earth.
key_findings: Successful genome sequencing of multiple Tremellomycetes isolates.
Identification of unique genetic adaptations to space conditions.
Insights into microbial resilience in microgravity environments.
OSD-290.study_publication_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Tremellomycetes strains Isolated from the International Space Station

OSD-291.short_title: Whole Genome Sequencing of Rubinsicoccus jepli
OSD-291.short_summary: Exploring the genome of a novel bacterium from JPL spacecraft.
OSD-291.summary: This study focuses on the whole genome sequencing of Rubinsicoccus jepli, a newly identified bacterium. Isolated from the environment of JPL spacecraft, this organism is significant for understanding microbial life in space-related contexts. The findings could have implications for astrobiology and the study of life in extraterrestrial environments.
OSD-291.description: Rubinsicoccus jepli represents a novel genus that was isolated from the unique environment of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) spacecraft assembly area. This study employs nucleotide sequencing to explore the complete genome of this bacterium. The research aims to uncover genetic features that may contribute to its survival in extreme conditions. Understanding the genomic makeup of Rubinsicoccus jepli can provide insights into microbial resilience and adaptation. The results may also inform future studies on microbial life in space and its potential implications for astrobiology. By characterizing this organism, researchers hope to expand the knowledge of life forms that can thrive in extraterrestrial environments.
key_findings: Identification of a novel genus, Rubinsicoccus jepli.
Whole genome sequencing reveals unique genetic traits.
Insights into microbial survival in spacecraft environments.
