The research aimed to profile gene expression against clone-, patient-, and passage-matched ground control samples. Utilizing real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR), the study assessed the impact of microgravity on the cellular behavior of CPCs. The experiment involved individual cultures of human CPCs from three neonates and three adults, both on the ground and in space. This research contributes to our understanding of how spaceflight may influence human health and cellular processes. The results could have implications for future long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Microgravity affects gene expression in human cardiovascular progenitor cells.
Adult and neonatal CPCs show distinct responses to spaceflight conditions.
Real-time PCR effectively profiles gene expression changes in space.
Comparative analysis with ground controls highlights significant differences.
OSD-344.study_publication_title: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties

OSD-345.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Mouse B Cells
OSD-345.short_summary: Study reveals spaceflight effects on mouse immune system development.
OSD-345.summary: This study investigates the impact of spaceflight on B cell development in mice. Using advanced proteomics, researchers analyzed femur bone and marrow samples from mice flown on the BION-M1 biosatellite. The findings indicate significant reductions in B cell populations post-flight, suggesting long-lasting effects on immune function. These results highlight the need for further research into astronaut health during space missions.
OSD-345.description: Bone loss and immune dysregulation are critical concerns for astronaut health during spaceflight. This study focuses on the effects of weightlessness on B cell development in mice, a topic that has been under-explored compared to amphibian studies. Mice were flown for one month on the BION-M1 biosatellite, and their femur bone and marrow were analyzed using mass spectrometry. The results showed a 41% reduction in B cells in the spleen one week after landing, indicating that spaceflight has lasting impacts on immune function. These findings suggest that astronauts may face increased susceptibility to infections post-mission. Understanding these effects is crucial for developing countermeasures to protect astronaut health in future space explorations.
key_findings: Spaceflight caused a 41% reduction in B cells in the spleen.
Adverse effects on B lymphopoiesis were most pronounced one week after landing.
The immune response remained intact despite B cell reductions.
Spaceflight impacts on immune function may increase infection susceptibility.
OSD-345.study_publication_title: Analysis of femurs from mice embarked on board BION-M1 biosatellite reveals a decrease in immune cell development, including B cells, after 1 wk of recovery on Earth

OSD-346.short_title: Arabidopsis Response to Spaceflight Gravity Changes
OSD-346.short_summary: Study explores Arabidopsis thaliana mutants under fractional gravity in space.
OSD-346.summary: This study investigates the effects of fractional gravity on Arabidopsis thaliana phytochrome mutants during spaceflight. By analyzing RNA sequencing data, researchers aim to understand plant growth responses under varying gravity conditions. The experiments were conducted on the International Space Station, providing valuable insights into plant behavior in extraterrestrial environments. This research is crucial for developing life support systems for future space missions.
OSD-346.description: As space agencies aim for missions to extraterrestrial objects with reduced gravity, understanding plant responses becomes essential. This study focuses on Arabidopsis thaliana, specifically phytochrome mutants PhyA and PhyB, to assess their growth under different gravity levels. Conducted on the International Space Station, seedlings were exposed to microgravity and partial gravity conditions, along with blue light stimulation. RNA was extracted from both wildtype and mutant samples for comprehensive RNA sequencing analysis. The findings will enhance our knowledge of plant tropisms and growth responses in space. This research complements previous datasets and contributes to the broader understanding of plant biology in extraterrestrial settings.
key_findings: RNA sequencing reveals differential gene expression in phytochrome mutants under varying gravity.
Blue light stimulation impacts growth responses of Arabidopsis thaliana in space.
Study enhances understanding of plant adaptation to extraterrestrial environments.
Data supports future life support system development for space missions.
study_publication_title: RNAseq analysis of the response of Arabidopsis thaliana to fractional gravity under blue-light stimulation during spaceflight
RNA-seq analyses of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings after exposure to blue-light phototropic stimuli in microgravity
Changes in operational procedures to improve spaceflight experiments in plant biology in the European Modular Cultivation System
A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity

OSD-347.short_title: Impact of Microgravity on Drosophila Heart Function
OSD-347.short_summary: This study investigates heart function in Drosophila under microgravity conditions.
OSD-347.summary: This research explores the effects of microgravity on heart function in Drosophila melanogaster. Flies were sent to the International Space Station for a 30-day mission to assess physiological changes. The study utilized RNA sequencing to analyze gene expression differences between spaceflown and ground control flies. Findings from this research could provide insights into how microgravity affects cardiac function and gene regulation.
OSD-347.description: The study involved laboratory wildtype Drosophila lines and a K+ channel mutant, which were launched aboard the SpaceX CRS-3 mission. Flies were housed in specially designed vials and subjected to microgravity conditions for 30 days. Data collection included negative geotaxis assays, heart function studies, and RNA sequencing. The experimental design ensured that the flies experienced consistent conditions throughout the mission. Following their return to Earth, surviving flies were analyzed to determine the impact of spaceflight on their heart function. This research aims to enhance our understanding of how microgravity influences biological systems, particularly in relation to cardiac health. The findings could have implications for human health in space travel.
key_findings: Microgravity exposure alters heart function in Drosophila.
RNA sequencing revealed significant gene expression changes.
Surviving flies exhibited physiological adaptations post-spaceflight.
Study provides insights into cardiac health in microgravity.
OSD-347.study_publication_title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosophila

OSD-350.short_summary: This study explores fungal genomes from the International Space Station.
OSD-350.summary: This study focuses on the genome sequencing of various fungal species isolated from the International Space Station. It highlights the genetic diversity of Aspergillus and Penicillium species in a space environment. The findings contribute to our understanding of microbial life in space and its implications for long-duration missions.
OSD-350.description: The research involved sequencing and assembling the genomes of fungal isolates belonging to the Penicillium and Aspergillus genera. These fungi were collected from the International Space Station and the Crew Resupply Vehicle Capsule. By analyzing their genetic material, the study aims to uncover how these organisms adapt to the unique conditions of space. The results may have significant implications for astrobiology and the safety of future space missions. Understanding these fungi can also provide insights into their potential applications in biotechnology. This work represents a step forward in our exploration of life beyond Earth.
key_findings: Sequenced genomes of multiple Aspergillus and Penicillium species.
Identified genetic adaptations to space conditions.
Provided insights into microbial diversity in space.
Potential implications for biotechnological applications.
OSD-350.study_publication_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Aspergillus and Penicillium Species Isolated from the International Space Station and Crew Resupply Vehicle Capsule

OSD-351.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Bone Health in Rats
OSD-351.short_summary: Study reveals spaceflight effects on bone microarchitecture in ovariectomized rats.
OSD-351.summary: This study explores how a 14-day spaceflight affects bone health in ovariectomized rats. It focuses on changes in bone mass, density, and microarchitecture in both weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing bones. The findings indicate specific deficits in cancellous bone volume and cortical bone accrual due to spaceflight. This research provides insights into the implications of microgravity on skeletal health, particularly in the context of hormonal changes.
OSD-351.description: The research investigated the effects of a 14-day spaceflight on the bone microarchitecture of ovariectomized Fisher 344 rats. Twelve-week-old rats were divided into three groups: baseline, ground control, and spaceflight. The study found that ovariectomy led to significant deficits in cancellous bone volume fraction. Spaceflight resulted in reduced cortical bone accrual in the femur, while the humerus and calvarium showed no significant changes. Notably, cancellous bone volume was lower in flight animals compared to ground controls in specific regions. The findings suggest that the effects of spaceflight on bone health are compartment-specific and not solely dependent on weight-bearing status. This dataset focuses exclusively on the ovariectomized rats, providing valuable insights into the impact of microgravity on skeletal health.
key_findings: Spaceflight led to lower cortical bone accrual in the femur.
Cancellous bone volume fraction decreased in lumbar vertebra and distal femur.
Ovariectomy resulted in bone-specific deficits in cancellous bone volume.
No significant changes were observed in the distal humerus.
Bone loss was associated with lower trabecular number and thickness.
OSD-351.study_publication_title: Effects of Spaceflight on Bone Microarchitecture in the Axial and Appendicular Skeleton in Growing Ovariectomized Rats from STS-62

OSD-352.short_title: Transcriptional Analysis of Spaceflown Mice Brains
OSD-352.short_summary: Study investigates brain changes in mice during spaceflight using advanced transcriptomics techniques.
OSD-352.summary: This study explores the effects of spaceflight on the brains of mice using multi-modal transcriptional and chromatin accessibility analyses. Mice were flown on the ISS for 39-42 days to assess the impact of microgravity on gene expression and chromatin structure. The research aims to provide insights into potential countermeasures for muscle and bone loss during space missions. Various RNA sequencing techniques were employed to analyze brain samples from both spaceflown and ground control mice.
OSD-352.description: The Rodent Research-3 (RR-3) mission, sponsored by Eli Lilly and the Center for the Advancement of Science in Space, focused on understanding the effects of spaceflight on muscle and bone mass. In this study, twenty BALB/c female mice were flown to the ISS, while ground controls were kept under similar conditions. After the mission, brain samples were collected and analyzed using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing techniques. The study utilized advanced methods to capture and profile gene expression and chromatin accessibility in the brain. Results from this research could inform future countermeasures for health issues faced by astronauts. The findings contribute to our understanding of how microgravity affects mammalian biology, particularly in the context of neurological health.
key_findings: Identified significant changes in gene expression in the brains of spaceflown mice.
Demonstrated the utility of spatial transcriptomics in studying brain tissue.
Revealed insights into chromatin accessibility alterations due to microgravity.
Provided a comparative analysis between spaceflown and ground control mice.
OSD-352.study_publication_title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice.

OSD-353.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Human Plasma Proteome
OSD-353.short_summary: This study investigates spaceflight effects on human plasma using mass spectrometry.
OSD-353.summary: This research explores how spaceflight factors influence the human plasma proteome through mass spectrometry analysis. It includes data from both real space missions and ground-based experiments. Blood plasma samples were collected from participants in head-down bed rest and dry immersion studies. The findings aim to enhance our understanding of human physiological responses to space environments.
OSD-353.description: The study focuses on the accumulation of proteomic data regarding the effects of spaceflight on human health. It involves blood plasma samples from ten healthy male volunteers, five from a 21-day head-down bed rest (HDBR) experiment and five from a similar duration dry immersion experiment. By comparing these samples, researchers aim to identify specific changes in the plasma proteome due to spaceflight factors. This research is crucial for understanding how microgravity and other space conditions affect human physiology. The results could inform future space missions and the health of astronauts. Overall, this study contributes valuable insights into the biological impacts of space travel.
key_findings: Identified significant changes in plasma proteome due to spaceflight factors.
Compared effects of head-down bed rest and dry immersion on human physiology.
Provided insights into potential health risks for astronauts during long-duration missions.
OSD-353.study_publication_title: The Effects of Spaceflight Factors on the Human Plasma Proteome, Including Both Real Space Missions and Ground-Based Experiments.

OSD-354.short_title: Human Muscle Remodeling Under Varying Loads
OSD-354.short_summary: Study reveals molecular regulators of muscle adaptation to different loading conditions.
OSD-354.summary: This study investigates the molecular transducers involved in human skeletal muscle remodeling under varying loading states. By optimizing RNA detection in muscle biopsy samples, researchers identified a core set of genes that regulate muscle growth. The findings highlight the complexity of muscle adaptation and the potential for targeted therapies to enhance muscle function. The study employs a novel within-person analysis strategy to reduce variability in muscle response.
OSD-354.description: The research focuses on the molecular mechanisms that govern human skeletal muscle adaptation to different loading conditions. By updating the annotation of the Affymetrix HTA 2.0 array, the study enhances RNA detection in muscle biopsy samples. A total of 141 core genes were identified, which correlate with muscle growth and were validated through RNA interference in primary muscle cells. The study's innovative approach detected significantly more regulated genes compared to previous studies, including those with selective regulation of untranslated regions. Additionally, the analysis revealed important connections between muscle characteristics, aging, and insulin sensitivity. These insights could lead to novel drug therapies aimed at improving muscle health. Overall, the research contributes to a deeper understanding of muscle biology and its implications for physical activity.
key_findings: Identified 141 core genes linked to muscle growth.
Optimized RNA detection improved gene regulation identification.
Novel analysis strategy reduced variability in muscle response.
Detected significant UTR-selective regulation of genes.
Revealed connections to muscle aging and insulin sensitivity.
study_publication_title: Molecular Transducers of Human Skeletal Muscle Remodeling under Different Loading States.
A coding and non-coding transcriptomic perspective on the genomics of human metabolic disease
Longevity‐related molecular pathways are subject to midlife “switch” in humans

OSD-355.short_summary: Study investigates miRNA responses to parabolic flight simulating weightlessness.
OSD-355.summary: This study explores the effects of weightlessness on human physiology by analyzing circulating micro-RNA (miRNA) expression. Using parabolic flight as a spaceflight analogue, researchers aim to uncover molecular adaptations in response to gravitational changes. The findings could provide insights into the biological mechanisms underlying human adaptation to space environments.
OSD-355.description: Understanding how humans react physiologically to weightlessness is crucial for the success of long-duration space missions. Previous studies have documented various organ system adaptations, but the molecular basis of these changes remains poorly understood. This research focuses on the expression of circulating miRNAs in serum during parabolic flight, which simulates the microgravity experienced in space. By examining these molecular responses, the study aims to shed light on how the human body adapts to gravitational changes. The results could have significant implications for astronaut health and mission planning. Ultimately, this research contributes to the broader understanding of human biology in extreme environments.
key_findings: Identified specific miRNAs that change in response to weightlessness.
Demonstrated the potential of miRNA as biomarkers for physiological adaptation.
Provided insights into molecular mechanisms of human adaptation to microgravity.
OSD-355.study_publication_title: Next-generation sequencing analysis of circulating micro-RNA expression in response to parabolic flight as a spaceflight analogue

OSD-356.short_title: Impact of Microgravity on Vibrio fischeri
OSD-356.short_summary: Study reveals how microgravity affects Vibrio fischeri gene expression.
OSD-356.summary: This study investigates the effects of modeled microgravity on the mutualistic bacterium Vibrio fischeri. By analyzing RNA sequencing data, researchers found minimal differences in gene expression between microgravity and normal gravity conditions. However, significant changes occurred during the transition from exponential to stationary growth phases. The study highlights the role of the Hfq regulator in influencing gene expression under microgravity conditions.
OSD-356.description: Understanding the relationship between astronauts and their microbiome is crucial for long-duration space missions. This study focuses on Vibrio fischeri, a mutualistic bacterium, and its response to low-shear-modeled microgravity (LSMMG). Cultures of both wild-type and Hfq mutant strains were analyzed under different growth conditions. The findings revealed that while few genes were differentially expressed between gravity and LSMMG, notable transcriptomic changes occurred during growth phase transitions. Specifically, there was a decrease in genes related to translation and an increase in stress response genes under LSMMG. The Hfq mutant showed a distinct transcriptome profile, indicating its significant role in gene regulation under microgravity. These insights enhance our understanding of how microgravity impacts beneficial microbes associated with human health.
key_findings: Minimal differential gene expression observed between gravity and LSMMG conditions.
Significant transcriptomic changes noted during growth phase transitions.
Hfq mutant exhibited increased transcripts related to flagellar synthesis under LSMMG.
Stress response genes were upregulated in LSMMG conditions.
Loss of Hfq alters gene expression in Vibrio fischeri under microgravity.
OSD-356.study_publication_title: Transcriptional profiling of the mutualistic bacterium Vibrio fischeri and an hfq mutant under modeled microgravityTranscriptional profiling of the mutualistic bacterium Vibrio fischeri and an hfq mutant under modeled microgravity

OSD-359.short_title: Proteome Changes in Exhaled Breath Post-Spaceflight
OSD-359.short_summary: Study reveals significant proteome changes in exhaled breath after long-term spaceflights.
OSD-359.summary: This study investigates the proteomic alterations in exhaled breath condensate (EBC) following extended spaceflights. By analyzing samples from Russian cosmonauts, researchers identified 164 different proteins, with notable changes observed immediately after landing. The findings suggest that EBC can serve as a noninvasive tool for monitoring health during space missions. The results have implications for understanding the impact of spaceflight on human health.
OSD-359.description: The research aimed to explore the proteome changes in exhaled breath condensate (EBC) due to spaceflight factors. Conducted under the Protocon experiment, EBC samples were collected from five Russian cosmonauts before and after long-term spaceflights lasting 169 to 199 days. A semi-quantitative label-free proteomic analysis revealed 164 different proteins, with the highest concentration detected immediately after landing. Notably, proteins involved in keratinization processes were enriched, and significant changes in KRT2 and KRT9 levels were identified. Additionally, the study highlighted the potential association between certain proteins and alterations in microbial composition. These findings underscore the utility of EBC for noninvasive health monitoring in space. The data contribute to the advancement of medical knowledge in extreme environments.
key_findings: Identified 164 different proteins in EBC after long-term spaceflights.
Significant changes in KRT2 and KRT9 levels post-landing.
EBC can be used for noninvasive health monitoring during space missions.
Enrichment analysis revealed proteins involved in keratinization processes.
Detected proteins may indicate changes in microbial composition.
OSD-359.study_publication_title: Proteome Profiling of the Exhaled Breath Condensate after Long-Term Spaceflights

OSD-360.short_title: Impact of Space Radiation on Mouse Metabolome
OSD-360.short_summary: Study investigates low dose space radiation effects on mouse spleen metabolism.
OSD-360.summary: This study examines the effects of low dose space radiation on the metabolome of male C57BL/6 mice. Researchers focused on three types of radiation exposures: γ-rays, 16O, and 56Fe, over a period of four months. The findings indicate significant changes in various metabolic pathways, suggesting potential long-term health implications for astronauts. The results highlight the need for further investigation into the impact of space radiation on human health during extended missions.
OSD-360.description: As space missions prepare for longer durations beyond Low Earth Orbit, understanding the effects of space radiation on human health becomes critical. This study specifically looks at how low doses of radiation affect the spleen's metabolome in male C57BL/6 mice. Researchers identified forty metabolites with notable changes in purine metabolism, fatty acids, and amino acids. Early responses were most pronounced in samples exposed to γ-rays, while longer-term effects were associated with high energy particles. Regression analysis revealed correlations between fatty acids and time, as well as degradation of purines. These findings suggest mitochondrial implications and potential long-term effects on DNA repair mechanisms. The study underscores the importance of monitoring metabolic changes in astronauts during deep space missions.
key_findings: Identified 40 metabolites with significant changes post-radiation exposure.
Early metabolic perturbations were most evident in γ-ray exposed samples.
Long-term responses shifted towards effects from high energy particles.
Fatty acids showed a positive correlation with time after exposure.
Purine degradation was positively associated with time post-exposure.
OSD-360.study_publication_title: Effects of Low Dose Space Radiation Exposures on the Splenic Metabolome.

OSD-361.short_title: Bacterial Genomes from ISS Surfaces Study
OSD-361.short_summary: Exploration of bacterial genomes from the International Space Station.
OSD-361.summary: This study focuses on the genomic analysis of various bacteria isolated from surfaces on the International Space Station. It is part of the Microbial Tracking 2 mission, which aims to understand microbial life in space. The findings contribute to our knowledge of how bacteria behave in microgravity environments. This research is crucial for future long-duration space missions and maintaining astronaut health.
OSD-361.description: The study presents draft genomes of multiple bacterial phyla collected from different locations aboard the International Space Station. These samples were obtained during the Microbial Tracking 2 mission (ISS-MOP), which investigates microbial diversity and behavior in space. The organisms studied include notable species such as Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus epidermidis. By sequencing these genomes, researchers aim to identify potential risks posed by bacteria in a microgravity environment. Understanding these microbial communities is essential for ensuring the safety and health of astronauts on extended missions. This research also provides insights into microbial adaptation and survival in unique environments. Overall, the study enhances our understanding of space microbiology.
key_findings: Draft genomes of various bacteria isolated from ISS surfaces were sequenced.
Identified diverse bacterial phyla present in the microgravity environment.
Insights into microbial adaptation mechanisms in space conditions.
Research supports astronaut health and safety for future missions.

OSD-362.short_summary: Study reveals key regulators of secondary metabolism in a human pathogen.
OSD-362.summary: This study investigates the regulatory mechanisms governing secondary metabolism in Aspergillus fumigatus. By analyzing mutant and wild-type strains, researchers identified key transcriptional regulators, LaeA and BrlA, that influence both developmental and vegetative secondary metabolites. The findings highlight the interconnectedness of metabolic regulation and virulence in this important human pathogen.
OSD-362.description: The research focuses on the biosynthesis of secondary metabolites (SMs) in Aspergillus fumigatus, a significant human pathogen. It explores the roles of global transcriptional regulators, specifically LaeA and BrlA, in controlling SM production linked to both development and vegetative growth. Through RNA sequencing, the study compares the transcriptional and metabolic profiles of various mutant strains to uncover the regulatory network involved. The results indicate that BrlA not only governs developmental SMs but also vegetative SMs and the hypoxia stress response, working in tandem with LaeA. This research provides insights into the complex cellular processes that contribute to the virulence of Aspergillus fumigatus. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for both fundamental biology and potential therapeutic applications.
key_findings: BrlA regulates both developmental and vegetative secondary metabolites.
LaeA is essential for preventing heterochromatic marks in the brlA promoter.
The study identifies a regulatory network linking SM production to virulence.
Transcriptional and metabolic profiles reveal equivalence between ΔbrlA and ΔlaeA mutations.
OSD-362.study_publication_title: An LaeA- and BrlA-Dependent Cellular Network Governs Tissue-Specific Secondary Metabolism in the Human Pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus

OSD-363.short_title: Inflammatory Gene Signatures in IIH Study
OSD-363.short_summary: Exploring gene expression in idiopathic intracranial hypertension related to microgravity effects.
OSD-363.summary: This study investigates inflammatory gene expression signatures in patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). It aims to understand the potential implications of these findings for astronauts experiencing visual impairment and intracranial pressure (ICP) changes during space missions. The research highlights the role of inflammatory processes and specific miRNAs in elevated ICP conditions. The results may provide insights into the neurophysiological alterations associated with IIH and similar conditions in space.
OSD-363.description: The visual impairment and intracranial pressure (VIIP) syndrome is a significant concern for astronauts returning from long-duration space missions. This study focuses on idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), a condition characterized by chronic ICP elevation without an intracranial mass. By analyzing gene expression signatures from exosomes in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and plasma of IIH patients, researchers aimed to uncover molecular pathways linked to ICP elevation. The findings suggest that inflammatory cytokines and immune cell migration are activated during elevated ICP episodes. Notably, specific miRNAs, such as miR-9 and miR-16, were found to be upregulated in higher ICP subjects. This research provides a preliminary understanding of neurophysiological changes in IIH, which may parallel alterations seen in astronauts with VIIP syndrome. Further studies could reveal underlying pathophysiological mechanisms relevant to space travel.
key_findings: Inflammatory cytokine-driven processes are activated during elevated ICP in IIH patients.
Specific miRNAs, including miR-9 and miR-16, are upregulated in higher ICP conditions.
The study suggests potential parallels between IIH and VIIP syndrome in astronauts.
Gene expression signatures were derived from exosomes in CSF and plasma samples.
OSD-363.study_publication_title: Inflammatory gene expression signatures in idiopathic intracranial hypertension: possible implications in microgravity-induced ICP elevation.

OSD-364.short_title: Inflammatory Gene Signatures in IIH Study
OSD-364.short_summary: Investigating gene expression in idiopathic intracranial hypertension and its implications for astronauts.
OSD-364.summary: This study explores the gene expression signatures associated with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) and its potential relevance to astronauts experiencing visual impairment and elevated intracranial pressure. By analyzing exosomes from cerebrospinal fluid and plasma, researchers identified inflammatory processes linked to increased ICP. The findings suggest that specific miRNAs may play a role in these responses, providing insights into neurophysiological changes. This research could help understand similar conditions in astronauts returning from long-duration missions.
OSD-364.description: The visual impairment and intracranial pressure (VIIP) syndrome is a significant concern for astronauts after extended space missions. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), characterized by chronic ICP elevation without a mass lesion, shares symptoms with VIIP. This study investigates the molecular pathways involved in IIH to better understand ICP elevation mechanisms. Researchers collected gene expression data from exosomes in patients with IIH, focusing on inflammatory genes and miRNAs. Results indicate that inflammatory cytokines and immune cell migration are activated during elevated ICP. Notably, miR-9 and miR-16 were found to be upregulated in higher ICP subjects. These findings may reveal underlying neurophysiological alterations relevant to astronauts experiencing VIIP syndrome.
key_findings: Identified inflammatory gene expression signatures in IIH patients.
Elevated ICP linked to immune cell migration and cytokine activation.
miR-9 and miR-16 upregulated in higher ICP subjects.
Study provides insights into neurophysiological changes in IIH.
Potential implications for understanding VIIP syndrome in astronauts.
OSD-364.study_publication_title: Inflammatory gene expression signatures in idiopathic intracranial hypertension: possible implications in microgravity-induced ICP elevation.

OSD-367.short_summary: Study reveals unique gene responses in bystander cells after radiation exposure.
OSD-367.summary: This study investigates the bystander effects of ionizing radiation on human skin cells using a 3D tissue model. It highlights how non-irradiated cells respond differently compared to those directly exposed to radiation. Key gene expression changes were observed in bystander cells, indicating distinct biological responses. The findings suggest that 3D models provide a more accurate representation of human tissue reactions to radiation.
OSD-367.description: Ionizing radiation can affect not only the cells that are directly irradiated but also their neighboring non-irradiated cells, leading to what are known as bystander effects. This study utilized a 3D skin model, EPI-200, to explore these effects in greater detail than traditional 2D systems. By exposing a narrow strip of the tissue to alpha-particles, researchers measured gene expression changes in bystander cells located at varying distances from the irradiation line. The analysis revealed significant upregulation of lipid biosynthesis enzymes and downregulation of pro-apoptotic proteins. Additionally, proteins involved in transcriptional repression were found to be strongly upregulated, indicating a shift in gene transcription mechanisms. These results underscore the importance of using 3D models to better understand the complexities of cellular responses to radiation.
key_findings: Significant gene expression changes observed in bystander cells after radiation exposure.
Upregulation of lipid biosynthesis enzymes UGT1 and PITPNB.
Downregulation of pro-apoptotic proteins BAX and ARHGEF5.
Strong upregulation of transcriptional repression proteins CHD6, CHD8, and WRNIP1.
3D tissue model reveals distinct bystander mechanisms compared to 2D cultures.

OSD-368.short_title: Gene Expression Changes from Alpha-Particle Exposure
OSD-368.short_summary: This study investigates gene expression in human skin models after radiation exposure.
OSD-368.summary: This research explores the biological response of a 3D human skin model to low doses of alpha-particles. The study reveals significant changes in gene expression at both 1 and 16 hours post-exposure. By utilizing a novel skin model, the findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms affected by ionizing radiation.
OSD-368.description: The study focuses on the effects of alpha-particle irradiation on a 3-dimensional skin model, Epi-200, which closely resembles human epidermis. After exposure to 0.5 Gy of radiation, differential gene expression was observed, with 16 genes affected at 1 hour and 150 genes at 16 hours post-irradiation. The analysis utilized BRB-Array Tools and gene ontology assessments to identify impacted biological pathways. Notably, genes involved in cell signaling, ion transport, and amino acid metabolism were significantly affected. The findings suggest that radiation exposure alters transcriptional regulation, leading to changes in cellular metabolism and gene expression. This research highlights the importance of using 3D models to better understand the effects of radiation on human tissues.
key_findings: 166 genes were differentially expressed after alpha-particle exposure.
NOTCH2 and AOF1 were key genes affected at 1 hour post-exposure.
Irradiation impacted cell signaling, ion transport, and amino acid metabolism pathways.
The study utilized a novel 3D skin model for more accurate results.
Significant downregulation of multiple genes was observed at both time points.

OSD-369.short_title: Gene Expression Changes in Skin Model Post-Irradiation
OSD-369.short_summary: Study reveals gene regulation in human skin model after alpha-particle exposure.
OSD-369.summary: This study investigates the gene expression responses in a 3D human skin model following exposure to alpha-particles. The research highlights significant differential regulation of genes at 4 hours post-irradiation. By utilizing a more biologically relevant model, the findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cellular responses to ionizing radiation.
OSD-369.description: The study focuses on the effects of 0.5 Gy alpha-particle irradiation on a 3-dimensional skin model, Epi-200, which consists of primary human keratinocytes. This model better mimics the human epidermis compared to traditional 2D systems. A total of 545 genes were differentially regulated, revealing critical biological pathways affected by radiation exposure. The analysis utilized BRB-Array Tools and gene ontology assessments with Panther to identify up- and downregulated genes. Notably, receptor-regulated pathways and chromatin remodeling processes were highlighted as key components of the biological response. The results suggest that upregulation of certain genes may increase sensitivity to cytokines, while downregulation could alter DNA methylation patterns. This research enhances our understanding of the cellular mechanisms involved in radiation responses.
key_findings: 545 genes were differentially regulated at 4 hours post-irradiation.
Upregulated genes included receptors and signaling molecules, indicating increased sensitivity to chemokines.
Downregulated genes included DNA binding proteins and helicases, affecting DNA methylation.
The 3D skin model provides a more accurate representation of human epidermal responses.
Findings contribute to understanding the mechanistic basis of cellular responses to ionizing radiation.

OSD-370.short_title: Impact of Bed Rest on Insulin Resistance
OSD-370.short_summary: Study reveals how inactivity affects insulin resistance and gene expression in young men.
OSD-370.summary: This study investigates the effects of physical inactivity on insulin resistance and gene expression in young men. After nine days of bed rest, significant transcriptional changes were observed in over 4,500 genes. The findings indicate that bed rest not only induced insulin resistance but also altered pathways related to mitochondrial function. Interestingly, some gene expressions related to inflammation increased despite the insulin resistance. The study highlights the importance of maintaining physical activity for metabolic health.
OSD-370.description: Physical inactivity is a known risk factor for insulin resistance, and this study aimed to explore its effects on gene expression. Twenty healthy young men underwent nine days of bed rest, during which their insulin action-related gene expressions were monitored using DNA microarray techniques. The results showed that bed rest led to insulin resistance and significant changes in the expression of over 4,500 genes, particularly affecting mitochondrial function. Notably, while insulin resistance was induced, there was an unexpected increase in the expression of genes related to inflammation and ER stress. After four weeks of retraining, many changes were only partially normalized, emphasizing the need for regular physical activity. Additionally, a trend towards increased DNA methylation of the PPARGC1A gene was observed. This study underscores the complex relationship between physical inactivity and metabolic health.
key_findings: Bed rest induced insulin resistance and altered expression of over 4,500 genes.
Significant down-regulation of 34 pathways related to mitochondrial function.
Increased expression of inflammation and ER stress-related genes despite insulin resistance.
Partial normalization of gene expression changes after four weeks of retraining.
Trend towards increased DNA methylation of the PPARGC1A gene post-bed rest.

OSD-372.short_title: Genome Sequencing of ISS Bacterial Isolates
OSD-372.short_summary: Study reveals genome data of bacteria from the ISS.
OSD-372.summary: This study focuses on the genome sequencing of various bacterial isolates collected from the International Space Station (ISS). It provides valuable insights into the microbial diversity present in space environments. The research contributes to our understanding of how bacteria behave in microgravity. The findings may have implications for future space missions and human health in space.
OSD-372.description: This repository contains genome assemblies for bacterial isolates from the genera Staphylococcus, Burkholderia, and Ralstonia, collected from the ISS between 2006 and 2015. The study is part of NASA's Life Science Data Archive experiment 13823, which documents the overall microbial isolation efforts. The isolates were obtained from NASA's Johnson Space Center and sequenced through NASA Space Biology awards. This research is crucial for understanding microbial behavior in space and its potential impacts on astronauts' health. The genome data can also inform future studies on microbial resistance and adaptation in extraterrestrial environments. Overall, this work enhances our knowledge of space microbiology and its implications for long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Sequenced genomes of multiple bacterial species from the ISS.
Identified microbial diversity in space environments.
Contributed to understanding bacterial behavior in microgravity.
Data supports future research on space health risks.
study_publication_title: Reference-guided metagenomics reveals genome-level evidence of potential microbial transmission from the ISS environment to an astronaut's microbiome
Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Burkholderia isolates from the potable water system of the International Space Station

OSD-373.short_summary: This study explores immune response changes in zebrafish embryos under microgravity.
OSD-373.summary: This research investigates the effects of simulated microgravity on the antiviral immune responses of zebrafish embryos. By utilizing RNA sequencing, the study reveals significant transcriptional changes associated with innate immune responses. The findings highlight the inhibition of critical signaling pathways involved in type-I interferon induction. This work contributes to understanding how microgravity affects immune function in vertebrates.
OSD-373.description: The study focuses on the transcriptional changes in zebrafish embryos subjected to simulated microgravity conditions. Researchers employed RNA sequencing to analyze the effects of poly I:C treatment compared to mock PBS treatment. The results indicate that simulated microgravity significantly inhibits the retinoic acid inducible gene (RIG)-I-like receptor (RLR) and Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling pathways. These pathways are crucial for type-I interferon induction, which plays a vital role in antiviral immune responses. Understanding these mechanisms is essential for assessing the impact of spaceflight on immune function. This research provides insights into the challenges faced by organisms in microgravity environments.
key_findings: Simulated microgravity inhibits RLR and TLR signaling pathways.
Transcriptional changes in immune responses were observed.
Type-I interferon induction is significantly affected.
Research contributes to understanding immune dysfunction in microgravity.
OSD-373.study_publication_title: Attenuation of Antiviral Immune Response Caused by Perturbation of TRIM25-Mediated RIG-I Activation under Simulated Microgravity.

OSD-374.short_summary: Study reveals lasting epigenetic changes in mouse brains post-radiation exposure.
OSD-374.summary: This study investigates the brain's response to proton irradiation, focusing on epigenetic mechanisms. It highlights significant changes in DNA methylation and gene expression in the hippocampus of mice. The findings suggest that radiation exposure leads to both immediate and prolonged effects on cognitive functions. This research is crucial for understanding the implications of radiation on astronauts and cancer patients.
OSD-374.description: The brain's response to radiation exposure is a critical concern for both cancer patients and astronauts on long-duration space missions. This study specifically examines the effects of whole body proton irradiation on the hippocampus of Mus musculus at two distinct time points: two weeks and twenty weeks post-exposure. Researchers assessed changes in DNA methylation, focusing on cytosine methylation (5mC) and hydroxymethylation (5hmC). They observed impairments in cognitive functions such as object recognition and spatial memory retention, which correlated with altered gene expression profiles. Notably, significant overlaps in DNA methylation changes were found between the two time points, indicating both specificity and retention of epigenetic alterations. Additionally, a novel class of DNA methylation changes was identified, characterized by fluctuations in 5hmC levels across gene bodies. These findings underscore the complexity of the brain's response to radiation and its potential long-term implications.
key_findings: Proton irradiation leads to specific and prolonged epigenetic changes in mouse brains.
Altered gene expression correlates with cognitive impairments post-irradiation.
Significant overlap in DNA methylation changes observed at 2 and 20 weeks.
Novel changes in hydroxymethylation levels mapped to neuronal function genes.
Study highlights potential risks for astronauts and cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.
OSD-374.study_publication_title: Bi-directional and shared epigenomic signatures following proton and 56Fe irradiation.

OSD-375.short_title: Transcriptional Profiling of Brachypodium in Space
OSD-375.short_summary: Study examines plant gene expression in microgravity conditions.
OSD-375.summary: This study investigates the transcriptional responses of Brachypodium distachyon seedlings grown in space. By comparing seedlings flown on the International Space Station with those grown on Earth, researchers aim to understand how monocot plants adapt to microgravity. The findings could provide insights into the broader implications for cereal crops in space environments.
OSD-375.description: Brachypodium distachyon is a model organism for studying temperate grasses, including important cereal crops. This research addresses a significant gap in our understanding of plant adaptation to spaceflight, as previous studies primarily focused on dicotyledonous plants like Arabidopsis thaliana. Seedlings of three different accessions were cultivated under controlled light conditions both on the ISS and on the ground. After a period of growth, the plants were harvested for RNA sequencing to analyze gene expression differences. The study's results will help determine if findings from dicots can be applied to monocots in space. This research is crucial for future agricultural endeavors in extraterrestrial environments. The data generated will contribute to our understanding of plant biology in microgravity.
key_findings: Identified transcriptional changes in Brachypodium distachyon under microgravity.
Demonstrated the feasibility of growing monocots in space.
Provided insights into gene expression relevant to cereal crop adaptation.

OSD-379.short_title: RNA Sequencing of Mice in Space
OSD-379.short_summary: Study examines liver transcriptional changes in mice flown on the ISS.
OSD-379.summary: This study investigates the transcriptional profiling of liver tissues from mice flown on the International Space Station. By comparing young and old mice, researchers aimed to understand the effects of spaceflight on gene expression. The study utilized RNA sequencing to analyze samples from both on-orbit and ground control mice. Findings contribute to our understanding of how spaceflight impacts biological systems.
OSD-379.description: In the Rodent Research Reference Mission (RRRM-1), forty female BALB/cAnNTac mice were flown to the International Space Station to study the effects of spaceflight on liver gene expression. The experiment included two age groups: young (10-12 weeks) and old (32 weeks) mice. Half of each age group was sacrificed on-orbit after 22-23 days, while the other half was returned to Earth for recovery before sacrifice. This comprehensive study involved a total of 160 mice, including various control groups. RNA sequencing was performed on ribodepleted total RNA from liver tissues. The data provides insights into the molecular changes induced by the space environment. This research is crucial for understanding the biological implications of long-duration spaceflight.
key_findings: Significant transcriptional changes observed in liver tissues due to spaceflight.
Comparison between young and old mice reveals age-related differences in gene expression.
Data includes samples from both on-orbit and ground control mice.
Study enhances understanding of spaceflight's impact on mammalian biology.

OSD-383.short_title: Genomic Variants in Bacillus pumilus from Spaceflight
OSD-383.short_summary: Study reveals genomic changes in Bacillus pumilus after ISS exposure.
OSD-383.summary: This study investigates the effects of long-duration spaceflight on Bacillus pumilus SAFR-032. The research highlights significant genomic changes, including increased methylation and variants, after exposure to conditions aboard the International Space Station. These findings suggest that spaceflight can induce lasting alterations in bacterial genomes, potentially affecting their resistance to environmental stressors.
OSD-383.description: Bacillus pumilus SAFR-032, an endospore-forming bacterium, was studied to assess changes in its methylation pattern following a 1.5-year exposure to space conditions on the International Space Station (ISS). The study utilized long-read sequencing techniques to compare the genomic data of ISS-flown strains with ground control samples. Results indicated an increase in genomic variants and m6A methylation in the space-exposed bacteria. Additionally, laboratory experiments demonstrated a potentially higher survival rate of the ISS-flown strains under high X-ray irradiation doses. These findings suggest that spaceflight conditions may trigger significant genomic modifications, which could have implications for bacterial resilience during long-duration missions. Overall, the study provides insights into how space environments can influence microbial genetics and behavior.
key_findings: Increased genomic variants observed in ISS-flown Bacillus pumilus.
Significant rise in m6A methylation after space exposure.
Higher survival rates of ISS-flown strains under high radiation doses.
Long-duration spaceflight induces lasting genomic changes.
Potential implications for microbial resistance in space missions.
OSD-383.study_publication_title: Long-read sequencing reveals increased occurrence of genomic variants and adenosine methylation in Bacillus pumilus SAFR-032 after long-duration flight exposure onboard the International Space Station

OSD-385.short_title: Impact of Seed Sanitization on Microbiomes
OSD-385.short_summary: Study reveals how seed sanitization affects E. coli persistence in lettuce microbiomes.
OSD-385.summary: This study investigates the effect of seed sanitization on the microbiomes of red Romaine lettuce. By comparing sanitized and unsanitized seeds, researchers found that E. coli persisted longer in plants grown from sanitized seeds. The research highlights the importance of seed surface sanitization for maintaining healthy plant microbiomes, especially in space environments. Understanding these dynamics could lead to improved plant health and food safety.
OSD-385.description: Seed sanitization is crucial for reducing microbial contamination on seeds, which can impact plant health and productivity. This study focused on red Romaine lettuce and mizuna mustard, examining how sanitized versus unsanitized seeds influenced the persistence of Escherichia coli. Conducted in controlled growth chambers simulating conditions aboard the International Space Station, the research utilized 16S rRNA sequencing and qPCR to analyze bacterial communities. Results indicated that E. coli was more frequently found in the root tissues of plants from sanitized seeds. Additionally, the microbial diversity in leaf tissues showed minimal changes over time or between seed treatments. The findings suggest that sanitization practices are vital for space missions and could enhance crop microbiome health, leading to safer food production.
key_findings: E. coli persisted longer in plants from sanitized seeds compared to unsanitized seeds.
Root tissues showed higher E. coli presence than leaf tissues.
Minimal changes in microbial diversity were observed over time.
Dynamic shifts in Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, and Bacteroidetes were noted.
Seed sanitization impacts the microbiome, crucial for space agriculture.
OSD-385.study_publication_title: Persistence of Escherichia coli in the microbiomes of red Romaine lettuce (Lactuca sativa cv. ‘Outredgeous’) and mizuna mustard (Brassica rapa var. japonica) - does seed sanitization matter?

OSD-386.short_title: Impact of Seed Sanitization on Microbiomes
OSD-386.short_summary: Study reveals effects of seed sanitization on plant microbiomes and E. coli persistence.
OSD-386.summary: This study investigates how seed sanitization affects the microbiomes of mizuna mustard and red Romaine lettuce. By exposing sanitized and unsanitized seeds to Escherichia coli, researchers observed significant differences in bacterial persistence. The findings suggest that seed surface sanitization may influence the plant microbiome, with implications for plant health and food safety.
OSD-386.description: Seed sanitization is crucial for reducing microbial contamination on seeds, which can affect plant health and productivity. This research focused on the impact of sanitization on the microbiomes of two leafy green crops, mizuna mustard and red Romaine lettuce, when exposed to Escherichia coli. The study was conducted in controlled growth chambers simulating conditions aboard the International Space Station. Plants were harvested at various growth stages, and their bacterial communities were analyzed using 16S rRNA sequencing. Results indicated that E. coli persisted longer in plants from sanitized seeds, particularly in root tissues. Additionally, minimal changes in microbial diversity were observed, with time being a more significant factor than the E. coli treatment. These insights could lead to healthier crops and safer food production in space environments.
key_findings: E. coli persisted longer in plants from sanitized seeds.
Root tissues showed higher E. coli detection than leaf tissues.
Minimal changes in microbial diversity were observed over time.
Time had a greater influence on microbial communities than E. coli treatment.
Seed sanitization may impact plant microbiomes and health.
OSD-386.study_publication_title: Persistence of Escherichia coli in the microbiomes of red Romaine lettuce (Lactuca sativa cv. ‘Outredgeous’) and mizuna mustard (Brassica rapa var. japonica) - does seed sanitization matter?

OSD-391.short_summary: Study reveals heat-shock tolerant Firmicutes from spacecraft surfaces.
OSD-391.summary: This study focuses on the draft genome sequences of heat-shock tolerant Firmicutes isolated from surfaces in a spacecraft assembly facility. The research provides valuable insights into microbial life that could impact space missions. Understanding these organisms is crucial for preventing forward contamination in space exploration.
OSD-391.description: In this study, researchers isolated heat-shock tolerant Firmicutes from spacecraft-relevant surfaces at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory's Spacecraft Assembly Facility. A total of 63 draft genome sequences were assembled and identified, showcasing the diversity of these microorganisms. The findings highlight the potential for these bacteria to survive extreme conditions encountered in space. Further genomic analyses can lead to improved methods for contamination prevention during space missions. This research underscores the importance of understanding microbial life in the context of planetary protection. The results may also have implications for astrobiology and the search for life beyond Earth.
key_findings: Isolated 63 draft genome sequences from heat-shock tolerant Firmicutes.
Identified diverse microbial species relevant to spacecraft environments.
Provided insights into microbial survival under extreme conditions.
Highlighted the importance of preventing forward contamination in space missions.
OSD-391.study_publication_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Heat Shock-Tolerant Microbes Isolated from a Spacecraft Assembly Facility

OSD-396.short_title: Impact of Spaceflight on Bone Healing
OSD-396.short_summary: This study investigates how spaceflight affects bone fracture healing in mice.
OSD-396.summary: This research explores the adverse effects of spaceflight on bone fracture healing in mice. Using a segmental bone defect model, the study reveals significant differences in healing processes between ground and spaceflight conditions. The findings highlight the molecular mechanisms that hinder bone regeneration in microgravity environments, which could inform future interventions for astronauts.
OSD-396.description: The study examines the impact of spaceflight on musculoskeletal health, particularly focusing on bone fracture healing. Utilizing a 2 mm femoral segmental bone defect model, forty male C57BL/6J mice were divided into four groups for comparison between ground and spaceflight conditions. After a four-week period aboard the International Space Station, various assays, including micro-computed tomography and transcriptomic analyses, were conducted to assess bone healing. Results indicated increased bone loss and altered gene networks in spaceflight mice, suggesting inhibited healing processes. Specifically, the RANK-NFκB axis emerged as a critical factor in the impaired regeneration observed in the spaceflight callus. These findings underscore the need for tailored strategies to enhance bone health during space missions.
key_findings: Spaceflight mice exhibited increased bone loss compared to ground controls.
A unique gene network associated with impaired healing was identified in spaceflight conditions.
The RANK-NFκB axis was central to the observed failure in bone regeneration.
Altered trabecular structure was noted in spaceflight callus tissue.
OSD-396.study_publication_title: Gene-metabolite networks associated with impediment of bone fracture repair in spaceflight.

OSD-397.short_title: RNA-Seq and RRBS in Spaceflight Mice
OSD-397.short_summary: Study investigates neuro-ocular syndrome in mice aboard the ISS.
OSD-397.summary: This study explores the effects of spaceflight on mouse retinas, focusing on neuro-ocular syndrome. Using RNA sequencing and reduced-representation bisulfite sequencing, researchers analyzed samples from mice that spent 37 days on the International Space Station. The findings contribute to understanding the biological impacts of microgravity on ocular health. This research is part of the NASA Rodent Research-1 project.
OSD-397.description: Under the NASA Rodent Research-1 project, this study examined the effects of spaceflight on the retinas of C57 BL/6J mice. Sixteen-week-old female mice were sent to the International Space Station and housed in animal enclosure modules for 37 days. The research utilized transcriptomic and methylomic techniques to investigate the spaceflight-associated neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS). By analyzing the retinal samples, the study aims to uncover the molecular changes induced by microgravity. This work is crucial for understanding how spaceflight affects vision and ocular health in mammals. The results may have implications for future long-duration space missions and human health in space.
key_findings: Identified molecular changes in mouse retinas due to spaceflight.
Utilized advanced RNA sequencing and bisulfite sequencing techniques.
Contributed to understanding neuro-ocular syndrome in microgravity.
Provided insights for future research on ocular health in space.
OSD-397.study_publication_title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina.

OSD-400.short_title: Fungal Genomes from the ISS Microbial Study
OSD-400.short_summary: Exploring fungal genomes isolated from the International Space Station.
OSD-400.summary: This study focuses on the draft genomes of various fungi isolated from the International Space Station. These organisms were collected during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment, providing insights into microbial life in space. The findings contribute to our understanding of how fungi adapt to the unique conditions of microgravity.
OSD-400.description: The research presents draft genomes of fungi collected from different surfaces aboard the International Space Station as part of the Microbial Tracking 2 mission. The study includes a diverse range of fungal species, such as Aspergillus unguis and Penicillium rubens. By sequencing these genomes, scientists aim to understand the genetic adaptations of these fungi in a microgravity environment. This work is crucial for assessing microbial risks during long-duration space missions. The data may also have implications for astrobiology and the potential for life beyond Earth. Overall, this study enhances our knowledge of microbial diversity and resilience in space.
key_findings: Draft genomes of multiple fungal species were successfully sequenced.
Fungi exhibit unique genetic adaptations to microgravity conditions.
The study enhances understanding of microbial life in space environments.
Findings may inform future missions regarding microbial risks.

OSD-401.short_title: Muscle Adaptation to Microgravity in Mice
OSD-401.short_summary: This study explores how microgravity affects mouse muscle adaptation.
OSD-401.summary: This research investigates the effects of microgravity on muscle adaptation in mice. By analyzing RNA sequencing data, the study reveals significant changes in gene expression and alternative splicing in the hind limb muscles of mice exposed to spaceflight conditions. The findings suggest that these molecular changes are crucial for understanding muscle physiology in microgravity environments. This work lays the groundwork for potential therapeutic strategies to mitigate muscle loss during space missions.
OSD-401.description: The study focuses on the transcriptomic changes in mouse muscles due to microgravity exposure. Researchers isolated RNA from the gastrocnemius and quadriceps muscles of BALB/c mice subjected to nine weeks of microgravity. They found that differential gene expression (DGE) and alternative splicing (AS) varied significantly between muscle types. Gene ontology analysis indicated that DGE and AS regulate different molecular processes, highlighting the complexity of muscle adaptation. Notably, certain transcripts related to muscle function underwent significant AS changes, while DGE was linked to translation and lipid metabolism. This comprehensive investigation provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying muscle adaptation in space. The identified alternatively spliced genes may offer targets for therapies to counteract muscle degradation during long-duration spaceflights.
key_findings: Differential gene expression and alternative splicing vary across muscle types in microgravity.
Gastrocnemius muscle showed more differential gene expression, while quadriceps exhibited significant alternative splicing.
Non-differentially expressed transcripts underwent critical changes in splicing, affecting protein function.
Microgravity-induced changes in gene expression were associated with translation and lipid metabolism.
The study proposes alternative splicing as a key mechanism for muscle adaptation to microgravity.
OSD-401.study_publication_title: Alternative splicing diversifies the skeletal muscle transcriptome during prolonged spaceflight

OSD-402.short_title: Single Cell Profiling of Spaceflown Mice
OSD-402.short_summary: Study examines transcriptional changes in mice bone marrow after spaceflight.
OSD-402.summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight on the bone marrow of mice using single-cell RNA sequencing. Forty female C57BL/6NTac mice were flown on the International Space Station, with age differences taken into account. The research aims to understand how spaceflight impacts gene expression in bone marrow cells. The findings may provide insights into the biological effects of microgravity on mammalian systems.
OSD-402.description: In the Rodent Research Reference Mission (RRRM-2), a total of forty female C57BL/6NTac mice were flown to the International Space Station to study the effects of spaceflight on their bone marrow. The cohort included both young (12 weeks old) and old (29 weeks old) mice, with half of each age group sacrificed on-orbit and the other half returned to Earth for recovery. This study utilized single-cell RNA sequencing to analyze transcriptional profiles from femur bone marrow samples. Ground controls were established to compare the effects of spaceflight with standard living conditions. The comprehensive design included independent ground controls, basal controls, and vivarium controls, totaling 160 mice. The results aim to shed light on the molecular changes induced by microgravity in mammalian bone marrow.
key_findings: Transcriptional profiling reveals age-related differences in bone marrow response to spaceflight.
Single-cell RNA sequencing provides detailed insights into cellular changes in microgravity.
Comparison with ground controls highlights the impact of spaceflight on gene expression.

OSD-403.short_title: Single Cell Analysis of Spaceflight Mice
OSD-403.short_summary: Study reveals transcriptional changes in mice bone marrow due to spaceflight.
OSD-403.summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight on the bone marrow of mice. Using single-cell RNA sequencing, researchers analyzed samples from mice flown on the International Space Station. The findings highlight significant transcriptional differences based on age and spaceflight exposure. This research contributes to understanding how microgravity impacts mammalian physiology.
OSD-403.description: In the Rodent Research Reference Mission (RRRM-2), forty female C57BL/6NTac mice were flown to the International Space Station to study the effects of spaceflight on their bone marrow. The study included both young and old mice, with half sacrificed on-orbit and the other half returned to Earth for recovery before sacrifice. This design allowed for a comprehensive comparison of transcriptional profiles between flight and ground control animals. Single-cell RNA sequencing was employed to assess gene expression changes in the humerus bone marrow. The results provide insights into the biological impacts of microgravity on mammalian systems. Understanding these changes is crucial for future long-duration space missions and their effects on human health.
key_findings: Significant transcriptional changes observed in bone marrow due to spaceflight.
Age-related differences in gene expression profiles identified.
Comparison between on-orbit and ground control mice revealed distinct patterns.
Single-cell RNA sequencing provided detailed insights into cellular responses.

OSD-404.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in mice during spaceflight.
OSD-404.summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight on gene expression in mice. Using single-cell RNA sequencing, researchers analyzed peripheral blood mononuclear cells from mice flown on the International Space Station. The study compares young and old mice, assessing differences in transcriptional profiles after spaceflight. Findings contribute to understanding how aging and space conditions affect immune responses.
OSD-404.description: In the Rodent Research Reference Mission (RRRM-2), forty female C57BL/6NTac mice were flown to the International Space Station to study the effects of spaceflight on gene expression. The study included two age groups: 12-week-old and 29-week-old mice, with half of each group sacrificed on-orbit and the other half returned to Earth for recovery. Single-cell RNA sequencing was performed on peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from both flight and ground control mice. This comprehensive approach allowed for a detailed comparison of transcriptional profiles across different conditions. The study included independent ground controls and basal controls to ensure robust data. Overall, RRRM-2 provides valuable insights into the biological impacts of spaceflight, particularly in relation to aging.
key_findings: Significant transcriptional changes observed in PBMCs due to spaceflight.
Age-related differences in gene expression profiles identified.
Comparison between on-orbit and ground control mice highlights spaceflight effects.
Study enhances understanding of immune responses in microgravity.

OSD-405.short_title: Single Cell Profiling of Spaceflight Mice
OSD-405.short_summary: This study explores the effects of spaceflight on mouse spleen cells.
OSD-405.summary: This study investigates the transcriptional changes in spleen cells of mice subjected to spaceflight conditions. By comparing young and old mice, researchers aimed to understand how age influences the response to spaceflight. The study utilized single-cell RNA sequencing to analyze the differences in gene expression between flight and ground control mice. The findings contribute to our understanding of biological responses to microgravity.
OSD-405.description: In the Rodent Research Reference Mission (RRRM-2), forty female C57BL/6NTac mice were flown on the International Space Station to study the effects of spaceflight on their spleens. The experiment included two age groups: young (12 weeks) and old (29 weeks) mice, with half of each group sacrificed on-orbit and the other half returned to Earth for recovery. This design allowed for a comprehensive comparison between spaceflight and ground control conditions. The study included a total of 160 mice, with various control groups to ensure robust data. Single-cell RNA sequencing was employed to profile the transcriptional landscape of spleen cells from both flight and control mice. The results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of microgravity on immune function. This research is crucial for understanding how spaceflight impacts mammalian biology.
key_findings: Transcriptional profiling reveals significant gene expression changes in spleen cells due to spaceflight.
Age-related differences in immune response were observed between young and old mice.
Single-cell RNA sequencing provided detailed insights into cellular responses to microgravity.
The study included comprehensive control groups to validate findings.

OSD-406.short_title: Transcriptomic Responses of Arabidopsis in Space
OSD-406.short_summary: Study reveals gene expression changes in Arabidopsis during suborbital flights.
OSD-406.summary: This study investigates the transcriptomic responses of Arabidopsis thaliana to suborbital flights. It highlights significant differences in gene expression between two flight platforms, Blue Origin and Virgin Galactic. The findings suggest that suborbital spaceflight can induce unique biological responses that are related to traditional parabolic flight effects.
OSD-406.description: The increasing availability of suborbital flights offers new opportunities to explore the effects of spaceflight on biological systems. This research focuses on Arabidopsis thaliana, comparing its transcriptomic responses during flights on Blue Origin and Virgin Galactic. The study found that gene expression varied significantly between the two platforms, indicating distinct biological responses. Notably, the responses were linked to central metabolic processes such as carbon and nitrogen metabolism. Additionally, different genotypes exhibited altered responses, suggesting that genetic background influences flight effects. The results underscore the potential of suborbital platforms to enhance our understanding of biological reactions to spaceflight. This research paves the way for future studies utilizing in-flight fixation techniques to capture real-time responses during various flight phases.
key_findings: Distinct transcriptomic responses observed between Blue Origin and Virgin Galactic flights.
Alterations in gene expression related to carbon and nitrogen metabolism.
Different genotypes of Arabidopsis showed varied responses to spaceflight.
Suborbital platforms provide valuable insights into biological responses to space conditions.
OSD-406.study_publication_title: Shared Metabolic Remodeling Processes Characterize the Transcriptome of Arabidopsis thaliana within Various Suborbital Flight Environments

OSD-410.short_summary: Study reveals biomarkers for ionizing radiation exposure in humans.
OSD-410.summary: This study investigates the transcriptional response of human leukocytes to varying doses of ionizing radiation. By analyzing blood samples from volunteers exposed to different radiation levels, researchers identified specific genetic biomarkers. These biomarkers can aid in early diagnosis and mitigation of radiation exposure risks for astronauts on long-duration missions. The findings have implications for developing lab-on-a-chip systems for real-time detection of radiation exposure.
OSD-410.description: Astronauts on long-duration space missions face significant risks from ionizing radiation, particularly from highly energetic heavy particles. This study aimed to identify dose- and time-dependent biomarkers that could be used for early diagnosis of radiation exposure. Blood samples from ten human volunteers were irradiated at doses of 0, 0.15, 0.30, and 1.5 Gy, with gene expression analyzed at various time points post-exposure. The results revealed a set of sensitive genetic biomarkers that correlate with radiation levels. These findings suggest potential applications in developing portable diagnostic tools for astronauts. The study underscores the importance of understanding biological responses to radiation in space environments. Overall, the research contributes valuable insights into managing health risks associated with space travel.
key_findings: Identified sensitive genetic biomarkers for ionizing radiation exposure.
Demonstrated dose- and time-dependent transcriptional responses.
Results support development of lab-on-a-chip systems for detection.
Study provides insights into astronaut health risks in space.
OSD-410.study_publication_title: Dataset for dose and time-dependent transcriptional response to ionizing radiation exposure.

OSD-411.short_summary: This study explores transcriptional responses in Arabidopsis seedlings to gravity changes.
OSD-411.summary: This research investigates how Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings respond to changes in gravity. By reorienting the plants and analyzing their RNA, the study sheds light on the transcriptional mechanisms involved in gravity perception. The findings contribute to our understanding of plant biology and adaptation to environmental changes.
OSD-411.description: The study focuses on Arabidopsis thaliana, specifically examining tissue-specific early transcriptional responses when seedlings are reoriented. Wild type and starchless pgm-1 mutant seedlings were grown in vertical Petri dishes for four days. After a brief 90-degree reorientation, RNA was extracted from various plant tissues, including root tips and cotyledons. The RNA was sequenced using NovaSeq technology to analyze gene expression changes. This research aims to uncover the molecular pathways plants use to perceive and respond to gravitational changes. The results may have implications for understanding plant growth and development in varying environments. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the complex interactions between plants and their gravitational environment.
key_findings: Identified transcriptional changes in response to gravity reorientation.
Analyzed differences between wild type and starchless pgm-1 mutant seedlings.
Demonstrated the use of RNA-Seq for studying plant responses.
Highlighted tissue-specific responses in various plant fractions.

OSD-412.short_summary: Study reveals microbial safety of leafy greens grown in space.
OSD-412.summary: This study investigates the microbial communities associated with leafy greens grown on the International Space Station. It emphasizes the food safety of these crops, ensuring they are safe for consumption. The research utilized both culturable and non-culturable methods to analyze microbial diversity. The findings contribute valuable insights into food production in space environments.
OSD-412.description: The VEG-03D study focused on the microbial characterization of multi-species leafy greens cultivated in the Veggie production system aboard the ISS. It involved the analysis of red romaine lettuce, mizuna mustard, and green leaf lettuce, along with their associated rooting pillow components. Using molecular and culture-based methods, researchers assessed the microbial communities present on plant tissues and Veggie chamber surfaces. Results indicated low levels of bacteria and fungi, confirming the safety of the crops for consumption. Additionally, community analysis revealed greater microbial diversity in the roots and rooting substrate compared to the leaves. This research provides critical information for future food production studies in space and highlights the role of the plant microbiome in a closed environment.
key_findings: Microbial safety confirmed for leafy greens grown in space.
Higher microbial diversity found in roots than leaves.
Low counts of bacteria and fungi on Veggie surfaces.
Study utilized 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing for community analysis.
Research supports future food production in space environments.
OSD-412.study_publication_title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station

OSD-413.short_summary: Study reveals microbial safety of leafy greens grown in space.
OSD-413.summary: This study investigates the microbial communities associated with leafy greens grown on the International Space Station. Utilizing both culturable and non-culturable methods, it assesses food safety and microbial diversity. The findings indicate that the leafy greens are safe for consumption, highlighting the importance of microbiological characterization in space agriculture.
OSD-413.description: The research focuses on the microbial communities present in leafy greens and Veggie pillow components aboard the International Space Station (ISS). It employs both molecular and culture-based methods to provide qualitative and quantitative data on microbial safety. The study emphasizes the food safety aspect of fresh crops grown in space, with results showing low counts of bacteria and fungi on the Veggie facility surfaces. Community analysis through 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing revealed greater microbial diversity in the roots and rooting substrate compared to the leaves.
